285,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","3/12/2019 05:00 PM","Supervisor","DRT",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F6","Unjustified overrides and lack of overrides monitoring

Even though the new overrides policy was approved in September 2018, the Supervised Entity is still developing the procedures and tools needed to perform the overrides according to the policy requirements. For overrides performed after the approval of the new override policy (September 2018), the rationales and the reasons are not being accurately captured in the application support tool, as there is no specific field to include them (e.g., no reference of the override approval in the minutes of the meeting, with unidentified rationales in the supporting documentation and application tool).These issues highlight a lack of traceability of the overrides over the final rating output. In the context of the inputs for the “Parent - subsidiary” model template, some of the answers to the questionnaire are overridden, without a proper monitoring of the case as an override (e.g. overrides of the inputs made to reflect the credit risk analyst opinion on the effective group support that the obligor receives). There is neither a follow up of these cases in the model validation, nor a way to identify them in the rating tool Rating Non Retail (RNR). This failure to register the overrides prevents the Supervised Entity from monitoring the said overrides, and it also prevents the Supervised Entity from completely assessing whether it should adopt adequate measures to improve the model due to a high number of overrides. The issues detected indicate shortcomings in the traceability and monitoring of overrides. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not meet the legal requirements set forth in this finding as it does not properly document the situations in which human judgment may override the inputs or outputs of the assignment process. This understanding is also reflected in paragraphs 203 to 207 of the EBA/GL/2017/16.

BCE fechou a medida de ""Overrides over the final rating"" mas ficou em aberto a medida de ""overrides over the inputs"".","O6","The Supervised Entity shall implement all the needed developments and technical adjustments to guarantee the full implementation of the new override policy. In addition, the Supervised Entity shall ensure the correct registration of overrides by adding a specific database input field for them and shall monitor all the overrides performed, meaning not only the ones performed over the final rating, but also the ones performed over the inputs, such as overrides in the answers to the overlay Parent Subsidiary template.",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","6/10/2022 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída",,"Overrides over the final rating - implemented (creation of specific database input field and monitor of overrides).

Overrides over the inputs - partially implemented. The IT developments made by NB allow rating analysts to flag existence of overrides to inputs and write in a comment box what was changed. However, it is not possible to check in RNR the information prior and after the override to inputs. Furthermore, the flagging of overrides to inputs is fully dependent on the analyst's act of ticking the applicable box. In addition, it is not clear to the JST whether changes to financial ratios or changes in other steps performed outside RNR are necessarily considered by all analysts as overrides to inputs. Could you please clarify?

(30/06/2022) NB has already updated its accounting loading template (excel files) and its risk analysis by adding the reconciliation between reported and adjusted financial items, allowing the understanding and traceability of the referred financial adjustments. (Please see the answer to finding #5)
It should also be noted that adjustments to financial items are in the methodology and  therefore are not considered as overrides over inputs.
On June 28th NB has on LDP models 135 overrides from a stock of 4.010 ratings assigned, which represent 3,37%, below recommended threshold of 5%.

NB has only 21 overrides over inputs in LDPs, which it considers to be immaterial, being most of these types of overrides related to the overlay Parent Subsidiary template (76%), a template that only has qualitative answers. The input that is being override can be identified in the comment field that justifies that override and this comment is included in the monthly report which allows registration and monitorization of these types of overrides.

Additionally, having the information prior and after the override over inputs automated represents a substantial IT development, which given the immateriality of these types of overrides will not benefit  the entire overrides monitoring process.
Please find attached the Overrides Report on June 28th.
01/08/2022: Overrides over the inputs - closed but we strongly recommend NB to start thinking about the future generation of RNR that allows to:
i) automatically upload financial statements from IES databases (e.g. Informa D&B);
ii) automatically calculate the  financial ratios and track any adjustments made by the analyst;
iii) track overrides to any inputs;
iv) communicate with other IT systems of NB in order to have up-to-date information about credit events, early warnings, etc.

v) flexibility, simplicity and quickness to change rating models' variables, weights, cut-offs of the rating grades, etc. ","6/30/2022 12:00 AM","Overides 062022_28.06.2022.xlsx","6/30/2022 06:17 AM","10/14/2024 08:03 AM"

286,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","6/9/2021 04:00 PM","Supervisor","DRT",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F7","Inconsistencies in the documentation of the rating assignment process
The rating procedures, manuals and guidelines are subject to the following inconsistencies:

a) The RNR tool assigns the group rating to both the name and “internal client ID” of the parent company. This practice may compromise validation and monitoring activities performed on the stand-alone ratings, in the case where the group rating is actually lower than then stand-alone rating of the parent company (i.e., through the application of the holding overlay).
b) In practice, the Supervised Entity considers a threshold of 97% portfolio rating coverage as acceptable, in terms of exposure to low-default portfolio (LDP).

c) There are neither detailed criteria on the selection of an external rating when more than one external rating is available, nor documentation on the criteria for the use of external rating of foreign entities as auxiliary data in the rating assignment process.

d) There is a contradiction between the “Integrated Companies” guidelines, which mention the revenue figure of 15% and 5% for an activity to be representative for a company, whereas the rating procedures manual includes 10%.
e) There are rating templates guidelines for which the risk factors weights do not summarize the weight value associated with the respective module weight.

f) The guidelines for the template “Construction” present only one factor to diversification considering two different assessment dimensions, while in the application support tool there are two different risk factors to assess.

g) There are misalignments between the rating assessment procedure manuals provided by the Supervised Entity, as for instance: the document “Manual General Guidance 03 05 2004” contains assessment steps (the peer review (page12) and the sanity check (page 3)) which are not incorporated in the document “Manual de Processos MR V2.1”. Indeed, in practice these assessment steps are not performed on a regular basis.

The rating assignment process is not sufficiently detailed and in some instances, it is implemented in a way that is inconsistent with the internal guidelines of the Supervised Entity. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not meet the legal requirements set forth in this finding as the process to obtain and update relevant information on obligor characteristics that affect PDs is undermined. This understanding is also reflected in paragraph 202 of the EBA/GL/2017/16.","O7","The Supervised Entity shall be responsible for maintaining consistency and transparency in all the documentation and in the supporting tool (RNR). In particular, the Supervised Entity shall:
a) Guarantee a clear identification of the group rating.
b) Formalize the portfolio coverage threshold and detail sound criteria for keeping an obligor unrated.
c) Detail the criteria on the selection of an external rating and on the use of external rating of foreign entities as auxiliary data in the rating assignment process.

d) Solve inconsistencies observed in the related documentation, by aligning the content of the guidelines with: a. The rating procedures manual. b. The modules (and weights within them) that are applied in practice. c. The application support tool (and risk factors assessed within it) that are applied in practice.

e) Ensure that all the process steps prescribed in the rating procedures manual are performed on a regular basis. The Internal audit will issue an opinion on the compliance of this obligation.",,,,,,,,"Risco Baixo","9/29/2022 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída",,"We will assess IA report once it is available and decide if the obligation can be considered closed.

287,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","6/9/2021 04:00 PM","Supervisor","DDA",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Data Quality","F8","Insufficient controls between the source data systems and the risk systems, due to the lack of a golden source approach.

Although the Supervised Entity has the capability to use the Data Warehouse (DW) as the main source of data, in fact the Supervised Entity does not have a golden source approach. This leads to the risk systems RNR and AGI, receiving data directly from the source systems. As a consequence of this practice, the following consistency controls are missing:

a) Consistency controls, to ensure accuracy of the data that is transmitted to the risk systems, from the data systems. Currently, only controls to assess completeness and detect duplicity of data are assessed.
b) Consistency controls, between the different risk systems themselves.

The current use and control of source data systems and of the risk systems does not ensure consistency between both environments and even within the environments themselves. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not meet the legal requirements set forth in this finding as it does not ensure that the institution collects and stores all relevant data to provide effective support to its credit risk measurement and management process. This understanding is also reflected in Article 77(1)(c) of the EBA/RTS/2016/03.","O8","The Supervised Entity shall implement changes in the risk systems in scope (RNR and AGI) in order to ensure that the said systems are subject to:

a) Consistency controls, to ensure accuracy of the data that is transmitted to the risk systems, from the data systems; particularly, to strengthen the controls in the supporting tool (RNR) on all DQ dimensions.

b) Consistency controls, of the data quality between the different risk systems themselves.",,,,,,,,"Risco Médio","9/29/2022 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída",,"Note: The JST will request the assessment of this obligation under a future IMI.

288,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","6/9/2021 04:00 PM","Supervisor","DDA",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Governance","F9","Incomplete specification of the governance ownership, for the end-to-end IRB data chain.

Although the ownership of the different systems / applications has been formalized for the IT and the business side, there is not an end-to-end owner. Several departments are responsible for each core module from the IT side and from the business side; however there is not an IT/Business owner of the IRB data chain from end-to-end. The governance framework of the IT data chain is not sufficiently detailed and formalised. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not ensure that the institution collects and stores all relevant data to provide effective support to its credit risk measurement and management process. This understanding is also reflected in Article 77(1)(b) of the EBA/RTS/2016/03.","O9","The Supervised Entity shall broaden the data governance scope in order to allocate responsibilities for the overall data chain (end-to-end), with a functional (Business) and technical (IT) overall responsible.",,,,,,,,"Risco Médio","3/30/2022 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída",,"Note: The JST will request the assessment of this obligation under a future IMI.

290,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","3/12/2019 05:00 PM","Supervisor","DRG",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Governance","F11","Lack of a formal framework for the monitoring of the rating system

Stemming from the 2016 recommendation of the internal validation, some monitoring activities are already being performed; nevertheless, the institution lacks a formal monitoring framework in terms of both policy and procedures. Hence there is no evidence of which monitoring analyses will be performed on a regular basis and which thresholds will be considered to trigger actions based on the monitoring results. The Supervised Entity has not designed a framework for the monitoring of the rating system. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not provide a framework for the monitoring of grades and pools. This understanding is also reflected in paragraphs 215 and 217 of the EBA/GL/2017/16.","O11","The Supervised Entity shall implement an effective framework for the monitoring of the rating system, namely in terms of policy, procedures and regular monitoring exercises. The monitoring policy and procedures shall detail, at least, roles, responsibilities and the monitoring activities to be performed.",,,,,,,"The Supervised Entity shall implement an effective framework for the monitoring of the rating system, namely in terms of policy, procedures and regular monitoring exercises. 291,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","3/12/2019 05:00 PM","Supervisor","GVM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F12","Shortcomings in the validation framework

Regarding the validation framework, the following shortcomings have been identified: a) Specific analyses set forth in the validation framework are performed jointly between the Validation unit, Gabinete de Validação de Modelos (GVM) and the rating department (DRT), such as methodological and application components performed on specific templates. Although there is no specific evidence of any practice that compromises the independence of the Validation unit, the wording of some paragraphs of the validation policy do not guarantee the leadership of the validation team on setting and leading the validation and testing to be performed by all stakeholders of the core corporate model. b) The validation framework does not comprise any analysis of data representativeness in terms of, for instance, geography, sector of activity, risk segment and turnover. c) No detailed ex-post analysis of the core corporate defaults is performed in terms of identification of main drivers of those defaults, even in the cases that the number of defaults is considered low and the statistical tests are not considered significant.d) The methodology validation component compares the robustness of the methodology applied by the Supervised Entity with new updates proposed by the third party vendor, namely new risk drivers and different weights assigned to the risk drivers. In 2016, the validation team classified the outcomes of this task (for a subset of templates) as negative, but even so the institution decided to not implement the new templates proposed by S&P-RS. Given that the Supervised Entity did not implement the new templates of S&P-RS, whenever the validation team carries out this analysis, the outcomes are expected to be always negative. Additionally, the validation team does not present any evidence demonstrating that the reasons presented by the Supervised Entity in 2016 to not implement the new S&P templates proposed in 2013 are challenged and still well-founded. e) The validation framework does not assess all the relevant templates applied to rate the core corporate obligors; for instance, the “Mercados” template used to assign a stand-alone rating to some obligors is not foreseen. f) The validation framework sets a traffic light approach (green, yellow and red) to assess the results of each validation dimension, but it does not establish remediation measures to be undertaken when unsatisfactory results are observed. The validation reports do not provide for an entirely sound assessment of the adequacy of the final PD estimates. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not meet the legal requirements set forth in this finding as it does not fully validate their","O12","The Supervised Entity shall update the validation policy in order to clearly state that even when the support of other internal departments is required (e.g. support of rating team), the validation activities are set and led by the validation unit. The validation framework shall be enhanced, detailing additional relevant analysis and tasks, particularly:
a) Representativeness analysis, considering the diversity of obligors being rated by the templates.
b) Ex-post analysis of defaults.
c) Prove that the reasons presented by the institution in 2016 to not implement the new S&P templates are well-founded.
d) Ensure that all the relevant templates used to rate the obligors are assessed, including, but not limited to, the template “Mercados”.

e) Define the remediation actions that the institution shall undertake to solve unsatisfactory results according to the traffic light approach.",,,,,,,"The Supervised Entity shall update the validation policy in order to clearly state that even when the support of other internal departments is required (e.g. support of rating team), the validation activities are set and led by the validation unit. The validation framework shall be enhanced, detailing additional relevant analysis and tasks, particularly:
a) Representativeness analysis, considering the diversity of obligors being rated by the templates.
b) Ex-post analysis of defaults.
c) Prove that the reasons presented by the institution in 2016 to not implement the new S&P templates are well-founded.
d) Ensure that all the relevant templates used to rate the obligors are assessed, including, but not limited to, the template “Mercados”.

e) Define the remediation actions that the institution shall undertake to solve unsatisfactory results according to the traffic light approach.","Risco Alto","6/10/2022 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída","004221000000301","JST feedback to NB follow-up report of 31/12/2021 - mail enviado em 17/2/2022
This obligation was assessed under IMI PD LDP and RE and the outcome was:
a) Implemented
b) Implemented

As such, the JST considers the overall status of the obligation as closed but with a reminder to NB that decisions on implementation of changes to S&P templates need enhanced governance and clear rationale.","3/31/2022 12:00 AM","20230331_TRIM-2018-PTNOB-3974_quarter_FollowUp","6/30/2022 06:17 AM","10/14/2024 06:27 AM"

292,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","3/12/2019 05:00 PM","Supervisor","DAI",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F13","Flaws identified regarding previous recommendations issued by the validation unit

The 2016 validation report included 5 recommendations regarding the LDP portfolio. Subsequently, in the 2017 validation report, 2 of those recommendations were classified as implemented. However: a) No robust evidence has been presented demonstrating that a full compliance has been achieved regarding those recommendations related with the negative results on the backtesting and methodology and application components of specific templates. b) Regarding the recommendation to establish a framework of monitoring of rating systems, the Supervised Entity classified it as implemented based on the approval of the governance framework alone. However, the Supervised Entity still lacks a formal monitoring policy and recurrent monitoring exercises, conditions which were not highlighted in the validation reports issued after 2016. There are significant flaws in the follow-up of previous recommendations from the validation unit. It is therefore the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not meet the legal requirements set forth in this finding as it does not fully validate their internal estimates. This understanding is also reflected in Article 13 of the EBA/RTS/2016/03.","O13","The Supervised Entity shall ensure that the recommendations issued by the validation unit are reflected in effective changes and improvements.

The internal audit shall review the closing of the recommendations, to verify if the measures taken to close the recommendation meet the expectation originally raised, when the recommendation was set.",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","12/10/2021 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída",,"JST (Fevereiro 22): Please deliver evidence of the actions/improvements described by NB in the previous follow-ups, including evidence of IA's review. 293,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","3/12/2019 05:00 PM","Supervisor","DRT",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F16","Risk drivers selection is not properly assessed, documented and monitored

No detailed evidence was found regarding: a) The tests performed in the course of model development to analyse correlation and overfitting of the risk drivers. b) The representativeness analysis of the model development sample with the institution’s portfolio. c) The results of the tests for each risk driver. d) The expert judgment considerations taken during the process of selection or exclusion of a driver. Additionally, the Supervised Entity does not have sufficient knowledge of the proprietary data from S&P used by the vendor company in the development of the Core Corporate model. No evidence was provided by the Supervised Entity that all relevant potential risk drivers were analysed, specifically transaction risk characteristics, including product or collateral types or both, as well as past delinquency. Additionally, no evidence was provided regarding the monitoring of risk drivers performance. The Supervised Entity has not provided evidence that the relevant risk drivers were adequately analysed. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not meet the legal requirements set forth in this finding as it does not properly consider the relevant risk drivers when assigning exposures to grades or pools. This understanding is also reflected in paragraph 57 of the EBA/GL/2017/16 and explained in paragraphs 53 to 55 of the ECB Guide to IM - Risk Chapters.

The Supervised Entity shall provide evidence that they have a detailed understanding for the rationale underlying the risk differentiation function development, including driver selection and the weights associated with each driver. This understanding of the rationale for the model development shall be supported by relevant empirical evidence on driver selection, representativeness analysis (including a comparison of the data used to build to model with its own population of obligors, to fully assess the applicability of the S&P model) and the use of expert judgment. If the Supervised Entity cannot provide evidence of a detailed understanding of the rationale underlying the risk differentiation function, they shall re-estimate it while documenting the rationale as described above.","O16","The Supervised Entity shall provide evidence that they have a detailed understanding for the rationale underlying the risk differentiation function development, including driver selection and the weights associated with each driver. This understanding of the rationale for the model development shall be supported by relevant empirical evidence on driver selection, representativeness analysis (including a comparison of the data used to build to model with its own population of obligors, to fully assess the applicability of the S&P model) and the use of expert judgment. If the Supervised Entity cannot provide evidence of a detailed understanding of the rationale underlying the risk differentiation function, they shall re-estimate it while documenting the rationale as described above.",,,,,,"For the purposes of considering and analysing all the relevant risk drivers for its model, the Supervised Entity is recommended to be mindful of paragraph 57 of the EBA/GL/2017/16 and consider, e.g.:
a) obligor characteristics, including sector and geographic location for corporates;
b) financial information, including financial statements or income statements; c) trend information, including growing or shrinking sales or profit margin;
d) behavioural information, including delinquency and the use of credit facilities.

The Supervised Entity is also recommended to be mindful of paragraphs 50 to 52 of the ECB Guide to IM - Risk Chapters, by: a) Taking appropriate measures to avoid overfitting. b) Ensuring that the PD models perform well on economically significant and material sub-ranges of application.",,"Risco Alto","12/30/2022 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída",,"This obligation is very relevant and may require some effort. In summary, NB shall:

1) recover all documents, e-mails, working files, etc. prepared by or in cooperation with S&P- Risk Solutions to fine-tune the LDP templates implemented in NB. In particular, NB shall gather evidence regarding:

i) risk drivers selection (which variables were tested; why some variables were chosen and other variables were ruled out; if variables were ""imported"" from S&P templates, NB should provide evidence of tests, simulations to NB portfolio, etc.)
ii) selection of weights associated to each driver (how weights were selected, what methodology was followed, evidences of discussions, tests, simulations, etc.)
iii) evidence of tests, simulations, etc. showing that S&P models were adjusted to NB portfolio.
2) test the adequacy of LDP templates considering the nDoD (portfolio level but also case-by-case basis).

The following inconsistencies were identified in the one year default rates calculated for monitoring purposes: a) Non-IRB obligors (Standardised which are rated by the model) are included in the calculation. b) There is evidence of obligors without any credit obligation observed at the beginning of the observation period who were included in the calculation. c) For years prior to 2010, there is not traceability on the monitoring exercise of the calculation and of the adequacy of the assumptions applied to compute the one year default rates. The calculation of the one-year default rates includes obligors that do not fall under the scope of internal models and obligors without a credit obligation at the beginning of the year. The DRG team has performed a monitoring exercise of the Long-run average default rate in 2018, however: a) No justification has been documented demonstrating that the selection of the timeframe applied by the Supervised Entity to calculate the long-run average default rate reflects the likely range of variability of default rates. b) The Supervised Entity has not inferred the Long Run Default Rate at risk grade level over the period selected for the computation of this estimate. The data for computing the Long Run Default Rate at risk grade level is available, in the monitoring report, only from 2010 onwards. c) The Supervised Entity applies a decay factor of 0.5 to each year prior to 2009 (i.e. the default rates for those years are weighted half as much as the default rates for the other years in the default history), due to different data collection and default identification procedures. The shortcomings in the determination of the likely range of variability of default rates, as well as on the long run average default rate itself, may impact the PD used in the estimation of RWAs. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the requirements set forth in this finding as it uses a methodology with flaws, for the determination of the likely range of variability of default rates, as well as the long run average default rates. 302,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","3/12/2019 05:00 PM","Supervisor","GVM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F23","F#23 Deficiencies regarding the validation activities

a) The Supervised Entity does not analyse specific templates on a regular basis, including overlay templates. In 2016 the Supervised Entity validated 4 specific templates from the Core Corporate templates. Those 4 templates were the only ones validated in the last three years. During this period, the remaining templates, some of them relevant (e.g diversified services), have been assessed only at the backtesting component level. b) Over the last 3 years, the validation exercises included different sets of backtesting tests (different observation periods and scopes) without a clear specification of: i) which backtesting results should prevail; and ii) how those results should be taken into account in the conclusions of the backtesting assessment. c) The discriminatory power results have been included only in the 2018 validation report and no acceptance threshold has been established in the validation framework. Additionally, the impact of overrides in the discriminatory power of the model is not evaluated individually. d) Some analyses are presented only at LDP level, i.e. the Core Corporate risk segment is not assessed individually regarding the following tests: i) backtesting by risk grade; ii) stability (migrations and PSI); and iii) granularity. e) Although currently immaterial, the number of overrides in 2014-2016 was above the test threshold and the validation team, with the exception of an analysis for the four specific templates assessed in the 2016 validation report, has not performed a specific verification/challenge of the reasons for those overrides. The validation reports are therefore not fully in line with the defined and documented validation process and do not provide for an entirely sound assessment of the adequacy of the final PD estimates. It is the understanding of the ECB that the Supervised Entity does not meet the legal requirements set forth in this finding as it does not fully validate their internal estimates. This understanding is also reflected in Articles 11 and 13(a) of the EBA/RTS/2016/03.","O24","Regarding the validation exercises, the Supervised Entity shall:
a) Perform the backtesting analysis of all templates every year, including overlay templates. Additionally, at least every 3 years all templates shall be subject to a full performance review.

c) Perform the analysis of the discriminatory power, in every validation exercise.
d) Perform the analysis foreseen in the validation methodology not only at LDP level, but also at Core Corporate risk segment level.

e) Establish recommendation thresholds for discriminatory power and analyse the impact of overrides on the discriminatory power of the model, as well as perform a specific verification/challenge of the reasons for those overrides.

f) The internal audit shall assess and review the performance of these activities",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","9/10/2022 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída","004221000000304","This obligation was assessed under IMI PD LDP and RE and the outcome was:

The Supervised Entity’s Low Default Portfolios PD models and estimates for RS1 – Core corporate, RS2 – Municipalities, RS3 – Project finance and acquisition finance, RS4 – Financial institutions and RS5 – Real estate were provided by a third party who used external data for the purpose of estimation. To this purpose, the Supervised Entity shall ensure that default data used for developing and calibrating internal models are representative of the DoD used for internal risk management processes and, in particular, for the default identification process. In particular, default data collected using the new DoD implemented in accordance with this Decision shall be used to the maximum extent possible and shall be complemented with default data based on the DoD in place before the adoption of this Decision, in order to ensure that the minimum length of the historical observation period used for the estimation of risk parameters as required in Regulation (EU) 575/2013 is met. Default data based on the DoD in place before the adoption of this Decision shall be appropriately adjusted to reach broad equivalence with the new DoD. Moreover, when external data is used for the purpose of estimation of risk parameters and differences were identified in between the DoD used in external data and the Supervised Entity’s internal definition, the Supervised Entity shall perform appropriate adjustments in the external data to achieve broad equivalence with the internal DoD. The internal definition of default (DoD) policy indicates that defaults with an underlying dispute between the obligor and the Supervised Entity are considered technical defaults, which is not compliant with the EBA/GL/2016/07. Under ECB decision ECB-SSM-2019-PTNOB-10, the Supervised Entity was granted permission to implement the new DoD according to the Internal Policy of definition of default. However, in the implementation analysis performed, some misalignments were identified:

315,"IMI-ME-4783/2020","4/6/2021 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Médias Empresas","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","F7","Insufficiencies regarding the calibration framework

The calibration framework is not sufficiently detailed in relation to all procedures, analysis and statistical tests to be performed, in particular: - The framework does not refer to the possibility of considering a different scope for calibration than the application scope of the model (including exposures for which the Supervised Entity has no IRB authorization) when duly and properly justified. Moreover the analysis that shall be performed considering the different scopes are not defined. - To assess the granularity is referred that normalised Herfindahl-Hirshman Index (HHI) should be below 15%, however the normalised HHI test is not described in the framework and instead it is presented the HHI and its thresholds, not being clear which test should effectively be applied. - A Z-test is defined to assess the homogeneity and heterogeneity, without being prescribed the necessary assumption of independency between proportions. Moreover, the confidence level defined for the Z-test to assess the heterogeneity between rating grades is not aligned between development and validation framework, and no rationale is provided to justify the difference (90% vs 95 confidence level for development and validation respectively). - The Powerstat / Gini test is not described in the calibration framework and is not aligned with AUC (i.e, Gini results differ from 2xAUC-1), without a proper justification.","O5","The Supervised Entity shall improve the calibration framework documentation with sufficient detail regarding: - procedures (in particular the requirement applied to the sample used for the Z test), - analysis (in particular the confidence level defined for the Z-test), - statistical tests (in particular the normalised Herfindahl-Hirshman Index (HHI) and the Powerstat/Gini test) underlying a calibration exercise, - exceptional cases where a different scope could be considered for calibration purposes than the model application scope shall be duly and properly justified. Moreover, specific procedures shall be defined to ensure that the application portfolio has a meaningful differentiation and quantification of risk; All statistical tests prescribed in the calibration framework shall be properly defined to ensure a consistent application, as well as the respective assumptions and thresholds that support their conclusions/actions.",,,,,,,,"Risco Médio","11/27/2021 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída",,"DRG: 5-11-2021

Pursuant to Article 179(1)(b) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, the institutions’ estimates shall be representative of the long run experience, while according to Article 49(3) of EBA draft RTS and paragraph 82 of EBA GL (EBA/GL/2017/16), additional observations to the most recent 5 years should be considered relevant when these observations are required in order for the historical observation period to reflect the likely range of variability of default rates. During the calibration exercise, several methodological choices were performed based on expert judgment that were not duly justified and documented, specifically regarding the segmentation and rating scale definition processes. The calibration segment analysis that lead to the chosen calibration approach was based on a preliminary analysis of the full portfolio and the respective behaviour of the One-year Default Rate (ODR). Issues were identified, namely:
- a representativeness analysis was not performed to extend the conclusion of the full portfolio analysis to the final Reference Dataset (RDS)
- risk drivers were expertly selected, and
- the cut-off values applied to the risk drivers were expertly defined.
Also, the final rating scale was based on:
- an exponential curve expertly selected to represent the scores distribution, which was fit with only the first 3 quartile points;
- an assumption of constant increase of 0.45 for the grades distribution, and
- adjustment methods, expertly defined, to obtain the final grades’ cut-off points.

No proper justification/rationale is presented in the calibration exercise report to the above mentioned expert options, which, in part, led to inadequate choice of risk driver selection that further evidence lack of meaning in the calibration segment option analysis.","O8","The Supervised Entity shall improve the documentation of its calibration exercises in order to fully cover all methodological and expert choices allowing a knowledgeable third party to independently replicate the exercise. The chapter of the calibration framework specific to the MoC calculation cannot be considered a complete MoC framework, since it does not define robustly the underlying procedures for the identification and documentation of deficiencies as well as for the quantification and monitoring of the estimation errors. Additionally, there are some formulas associated with the quantification of the MoC estimates that are incorrectly stated in the framework, as well as in the calibration exercise report, and are only correctly implemented in the support files. Moreover, the Supervised Entity’s process for identifying deficiencies is not complete, as relevant weaknesses identified in this investigation were not considered or analysed as potential sources of bias in the PD estimate, such as (a) the assumptions that are performed to obtain a final score that has incorporated adjustments and/or overrides performed by the analysts, and (b) the classification as “Unrated” of obligors that are no longer in default when applied the historical reprocessing of defaults, disregarding information that may possibly be available in their systems; Additionally, the Supervised Entity does not prescribe in the framework the analysis of whether obligors that migrate to a different rating grade or rating model bias the default rate, applying a proper adjustment if needed.","O9","The Supervised Entity shall improve its Margin of Conservatism (MoC) framework to ensure it is complete, comprehensive and overarching. This framework shall contain (i) a process to identify all sources of uncertainties in the estimation of the risk parameters, to measure the materiality of the identified source of uncertainties, as well as a process to (ii) quantify and (iii) monitor their potential impact. Among other sources of uncertainties, the framework shall include: - the analysis of whether obligors that migrate to a different rating grade or rating model bias the default rate; - the deficiencies identified in the default flag construction process; - the data treatment performed within the risk modelling database. The MoC framework shall be reliable, therefore the Supervised Entity shall ensure that the formulas associated with the quantification of the MoC estimates stated in the framework are correct. The framework currently defined by the Supervised Entity for the model under scope presents the following weaknesses:
- A less deep approach is foreseen to validate non-material models however it is not established the scope, procedures and tests that should be performed under this approach.
- The regular annual validation does not include the following assessments: i) tracking of the number and reasons for technical past-due situations; ii) representativeness analysis.

- Regarding the data quality and data treatment assessment, it is not detailed, neither for the initial nor the regular validation, which tests and exercises will be carried out, neither the metrics/thresholds that would support the test outcome (in a quantitative perspective) and conclusions.

- The frequency for which some analysis should be regularly performed is not defined, namely: i) model design and stability; ii) benchmarking analysis, iii) assessment of legal or macroeconomic changes that may impact the risk parameters. Additionally, the following additional qualitative assessment aspects are not included in the framework: i) integrity of the rating assignment process and ii) use of the models and their correct application in practice.
- A homogeneity test is prescribed but with no indication of how it should be assessed and measured.

- A heterogeneity test for two adjacent risk grades is prescribed indicating the application of a z-test, however throughout the document such test is not defined nor indicated its interpretation.","O12","The Supervised Entity shall update the validation framework in order to clearly state and detail the validation methods, procedures and tests foreseen to validate non-material models. Additionally, the validation framework shall be improved by: - Defining for regular annual validation, the evaluation of input data concerning the tracking of number and reasons for technical past-due situations and analyses of representativeness; - Clearly defining the data quality and data treatment assessment performed, identifying and detailing the tests and exercises that will be carried out by internal validation, and also describing the metrics/thresholds/guidelines that will support the outcomes of the assessment; - Clearly defining the frequency for all analysis, namely regarding i) model design and stability; ii) benchmarking analysis, iii) assessment of legal or macroeconomic changes that may impact the risk parameters; - Including in the framework the qualitative assessments regarding i) integrity of the rating assignment process and ii) use of the models and their correct application in practice; - Defining guidelines on how the qualitative conclusions are reached (and can override a negative/red quantitative outcome) both for initial and annual validation exercises; - Defining and detailing the measures applied for assessment of homogeneity and heterogeneity tests.",,,,,,,,"Risco Médio","11/27/2021 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída","004222000000203","Following up on the exchanges below regarding obligation 12 of IMI 4783, we agree to close this obligation under the following conditions:

v) GVM will enhance its validation framework on the components related to rating assignment and model usage of Medium Enterprises models within the same timeframe foreseen to the implementation of Obligation #12 of the IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908 (August 2023).
vii) GVM will update the validation framework replacing the ""Z distribution"" statistical test by the Chi-Square test (when assessing homogeneity).
Status JST 7/3/2022
Status point of the requirements of the obligation:
i)  update the validation framework in order to clearly state and detail the validation methods, procedures and tests foreseen to validate non-material models => closed.

ii) Defining for regular annual validation, the evaluation of input data concerning the tracking of number and reasons for technical past-due situations and analyses of representativeness => we acknowledge the reference to identification of technical defaults. However it is not clear that ""the reasons for technical past-due situations are tracked"" (quoted from ECB Guide to internal models). Please clarify this in a future version of the validation framework. Open

iii) Clearly defining the data quality and data treatment assessment performed, identifying and detailing the tests and exercises that will be carried out by internal validation, and also describing the metrics/thresholds/guidelines that will support the outcomes of the assessment => we ackowledge the note GVM inserted in page 18 of the framework (v18). Closed

iv) Clearly defining the frequency for all analysis, namely regarding i) model design and stability; ii) benchmarking analysis, iii) assessment of legal or macroeconomic changes that may impact the risk parameters => we understand that these requirements are broadly included in the annual validation exercises. Closed

v) Including in the framework the qualitative assessments regarding i) integrity of the rating assignment process and ii) use of the models and their correct application in practice => We were not able to find the answer to this point in NB's validation framework. Please clarify.

vi) Defining guidelines on how the qualitative conclusions are reached (and can override a negative/red quantitative outcome) both for initial and annual validation exercises => we understand that each validation dimension has an overall conclusion but we do not see how GVM goes from each dimension to the overall conclusion. Having a single table (like the one in page 124 for LDPs) may help. Could you consider clarifying?

vii)  Defining and detailing the measures applied for assessment of homogeneity and heterogeneity tests => we understand that NB included moe detail in the framework. However, some sentences quoted below are not totally clear (p 178). Please clarify the rationale.

Tendo em consideração o propósito do teste, e com objetivo de avaliar a homogeneidade, o teste que se propõe realizar consiste em retirar uma amostra aleatória de 50% da subpopulação em estudo, e comparar a heterogeneidade entre as diversas classes aplicando o teste Z referido no ponto anterior.
Se se confirmar a heterogeneidade desta amostra aleatória, então podemos assumir que as classes em análise contemplam características específicas homogéneas entre si.""

IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433","3/23/2022 05:00 PM","Supervisor","DDA","DDA-GQD",,"IRB","PD e LGD","Crédito Habitação","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","F2","The data quality framework in place does not provide full coverage of the IRB data chain
The Data Quality Framework of the Supervised Entity is not effectively implemented through the IRB data chain, according to the following:

- The framework does not allow a comprehensive coverage of the IRB process, as some inputs are not in the Golden Source and the main variables of the process are not fully tested along the data life cycle, this is, from data entry to reporting.
- The data quality reports on model inputs do not reflect a data quality assessment along the IRB data chain from an end-to-end perspective performed on a regular basis.

- There is lack of articulation between the stakeholders, namely in the definition of critical elements, controls, business metrics and analysis of exceptions, evidenced by the data quality reports analysis.

- There is lack of integrated and systematic metrics to allow a proper monitoring and reporting process, evidenced through the inexistence of thresholds/tolerance levels for the executions of the regular controls in place.

- The formal documentation for the data governance and data quality process is insufficient or outdated. There is lack of formal documentation for the data governance and data quality process.","O2.A","The Supervised Entity shall:

(i) ensure that the data quality framework is effective, namely that controls are correctly implemented (according to their purpose) and adequate in terms of (a) criticality of the variables analysed in the data quality control; (b) analysis over the exceptions (root cause and severity of the exception); and (c) follow up/recommendations (including defining a remedial action plan and responsible department), and that it provides a full coverage of all data used in the end-to-end IRB-related processes (from data entry to reporting);

(ii) put in place an effective control framework to ensure a sound data quality over the entire IRB data life cycle, through the definition and implementation of measurements in an integrated and systematic manner and on a regular basis. Manual inputs (e.g. costs, information on foreclosure and sale value, etc.) shall be subject to specific controls; and

The program requires actions in 3 dimensions:

(ii) recovery of historical critical data, for IRB models
(iii) reinforcement of DQ control, for IRB models
The data remediation  program PMO was reorganized , to make it more effective in articulation with IRB OP PMO.

• REO’s (Real State Owned) phase II – IDE 102842 - in development / UAT testing - on time;

• Recovery cash-flows (collections) – IDE 104552 - EDW model to aggregate operational data (amortized credit, leasing ...) and recoveries data (SBRC) to produce a consolidated view on  contacts collections (payments) – software in production; historical data being recovered;

• Recovery Costs – aggregate recovery direct and indirect costs, on a cost model. Improve costs registration on the different applications (SBRC, SAP) - on going, on time; historical data recovered;
• Credit Sales – implement controls on the existing credit sales EUC solution - on going, on time;
• Restructured loans – recover restructured loans historical data - done (for mortgage); on going for commercial credit

• Collaterals – SAS to use EDW / DD collaterals data to replace “factual de collaterals” - done

• LTVs –SAS to use the new EDW / DD LTVs (for mortgage and commercial credit) - done.

Pursuant to Article 144(1)(h) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, the institution has demonstrated that “the institution has assigned and continues with assigning each exposure in the range of application of a rating system to a rating grade or pool of this rating system; the institution has assigned and continues with assigning each exposure in the range of application of an approach for equity exposures to this internal models approach.”

Additionally, pursuant to Article 174 (c) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 “the data used to build the model shall be representative of the population of the institution's actual obligors or exposures.”

The definition of unscored facilities is inconsistent between the sample used for calibration purposes and the application portfolio. While in the risk-modelling database they result from technical issues in the scoring engine, in the application portfolio the unscored facilities result from the inability to read the score from a specific table (FP_M_COR_SCORE_ME), during the capital requirement calculation process. Therefore, there is no evidence to assign a PD lower than the one from the worst performing risk grade.

For these reasons, the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out in this finding, since the Supervised Entity does not assign unscored facilities to the worst-performing risk grades.","O7","The Supervised Entity shall ensure that all mortgage exposures are scored by the automatic scoring model.In exceptional cases, when it is not possible to calculate a score, a conservative approach should be developed and applied.",,,,,,,"The Supervised Entity shall apply the PD from the worst performing risk grade to unscored facilities of the residential mortgage portfolio of the behaviour PD model.

IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433","3/23/2022 05:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","Crédito Habitação","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F12","Deficiencies in the haircut calculation
The haircut for repossessed collaterals was estimated by the institution, however several deficiencies were identified, namely:

- The haircut equation incorporated in its denominator the repossessed collateral amount added by the collateral costs discounted to the repossession date, leading to an underestimation of the estimated haircut.
- The institution considers as an observed haircut information where a full year has not yet been observed and uses this information for the estimation.
- The discount rate applied in the haircut estimation in not aligned with the discount rate for the remaining cash flows (use of discount rate at repossession date).

- The methodological approach considered for estimating haircuts in periods not yet observed lack in rationale and does not incorporate the loss associated to the collaterals not sold neither the time to sell of the assets.
- No analysis was performed to assess possible drivers of segmentation related to the properties that may best estimate the haircut and no sensitivity analyses with different haircuts was performed.

The databased used for the haircut estimation was not subject to a data quality analysis and no outlier treatment was performed by the development team, leading to the use of extreme observed haircuts.","O11","The Supervised Entity shall revise the formula and methodological assumptions regarding the haircut applied over the collaterals repossessed but not yet sold. In particular, the Supervised Entity shall
- properly justify the methodological choices made in order to estimate the haircut;

- ensure an accurate estimation of the haircut (e.g. observed haircuts shall be based on a full year of observation, no cost shall be included in the denominator of the formula, the estimation shall take into consideration the time to sell and the loss associated to the collaterals not yet sold); and
- apply the regulatory discount rate (Euribor 3M at the default date).
An assessment over possible drivers of segmentation and sensitivity analysis using different haircuts estimation shall be performed.

Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall perform a data quality analysis over the inputs for haircut calculation in order to mitigate any source of material biases.","5","1","2","3",,,,"Risco Médio","2/29/2024 04:00 PM","Final","1","Concluída","4222000000322","(31/03/2023) To Started.

IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433","3/23/2022 05:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","Crédito Habitação","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F13","Deficiencies in the Realised LGD Calculation

Pursuant to Article 174(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “the model shall have good predictive power and capital requirements shall not be distorted as a result of its use. The input variables shall form a reasonable and effective basis for the resulting predictions. The model shall not have material biases”.
The calculation of the realised LGD evidences several issues, that were confirmed in the selected case analysis, namely:
- Recovery Cash flow allocation:
i) evidenced an incorrect allocation of an “artificial cash flow” when a cure end-state did not occur,
ii) cash flows related to collateral sale are considered when the facility had no collateral at default date,
iii) lack of consideration of the credit sale recovery cash flow whenever a foreclosure occurs prior to the credit sale date.
- Cost allocation:
i) Costs are considered until the date of the end-state classification instead of the date of return to non-defaulted status (or cut-off date),

ii) The cost rate from the cured end-state is assumed and applied in the first 12 months of the recovery process, without a documented rationale and ignoring the effective end-state that occurred during that period,
iii) For facilities where a collateral sale was verified, all collateral costs are assumed to have occurred at the sale date and not through the time since repossession date,
iv) The cost of the restructured facility was incorrectly accounted since no costs are considered after the restructuring date.

Moreover, in the input data for LGD Realised calculation, several individual data issues were found which lead to incorrect situations concerning the identification of the default, EAD, end-state and abnormally low or high realised LGD. Upon assessment of the institution’s methodology for the identification and selection of relevant risk drivers, and determination of the final LGD pools, the following deficiencies were identified:
- The realised LGD with a floor of 0% was used to evaluate the loss characteristics of each facility,
- Lack of plausibility and statistical judgement in the assessment of transaction-related risk characteristics identified as potential risk drivers.
- Some methodological choices regarding the final pools for the LTV risk driver were made without a proper rationale and support.
- The use of the Two Proportions Z-Test for homogeneity and heterogeneity testing at risk driver level is not an adequate metric in light of the realised LGD nature,

- No analysis evidencing the homogeneity of the risk within pools and demonstrating a meaningful risk differentiation across pools, of the LGD model.","O13","The Supervised Entity shall have a proper risk driver selection process in place that provides for

IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433","3/23/2022 05:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","Crédito Habitação","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F17","Erroneous LRA LGD calculation and inadequate treatment of incomplete recovery processes

Pursuant to Article 179(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, ‘’an institution's own estimates of the risk parameters LGD shall incorporate all relevant data, information and methods. The estimates shall be derived using both historical experience and empirical evidence, and not based purely on judgemental considerations. The estimates shall be plausible and intuitive and shall be based on the material drivers of the respective risk parameters’’.

Pursuant to Article 181(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “institutions shall estimate LGDs by facility grade or pool on the basis of the average realised LGDs by facility grade or pool using all observed defaults within the data sources (default weighted average)”.
To obtain the LRA LGD, the institution considers a treatment of incomplete recovery processes where:

- the time-to-workout of 72 months and an assumption that facilities are sold in a credit sale at the end of month 72, both of which were not supported by historical experience and empirical evidence,
- All observed recoveries and costs are disregarded after 72 months,

- For closed default events prior to month 72 (except facilities that closed due to cure or credit sale), the institution considers the observed recoveries and costs until month 72, adding an estimated credit sale recovery cash flow at month 72, based on the outstanding amount at date of closure of the default event,
- The probability of not selling the credit obligation and an estimated credit sale haircut are calculated and applied in month 72 and are inadequately calculated.

For these reasons, the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out in this finding, since the Supervised Entity uses erroneous assumptions in the incomplete recovery processes which impact the calculation of the LRA LGD.","O15","The Supervised Entity shall ensure that all relevant information from incomplete recovery processes is taken into account in a conservative manner for the purposes of all LGD estimations (LRA, DT, DA).
In addition, the Supervised Entity shall comply in
i) accounting all observed costs and recoveries; and
ii) estimating future costs and recoveries within the defined maximum period of the recovery process, taking into account only costs and recoveries realised up to the moment of estimation.

Pursuant to Article 181(1)(b) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, ‘’institutions shall use LGD estimates that are appropriate for an economic downturn if those are more conservative than the long-run average’’.

IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433","3/23/2022 05:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","Crédito Habitação","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F21","Inadequacy of the ELbe estimation process

Pursuant to Article 175(4)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “the institution shall document their methodologies. This material shall: (a) provide a detailed outline of the theory, assumptions and mathematical and empirical basis of the assignment of estimates to grades, individual obligors, exposures, or pools, and the data source(s) used to estimate the model”.

Pursuant to Article 181(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “institutions shall estimate LGDs by facility grade or pool on the basis of the average realised LGDs by facility grade or pool using all observed defaults within the data sources (default weighted average)”.

Pursuant to Article 181(1)(h) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “for the specific case of exposures already in default, the institution shall use the sum of its best estimate of expected loss for each exposure given current economic circumstances and exposure status and its estimate of the increase of loss rate caused by possible additional unexpected losses during the recovery period, i.e. between date of default and final liquidation of the exposure”.
The ELbe estimation methodology applied by the institution is inadequate and evidences several deficiencies:
- The LRA LGD for non-defaulted exposures is used for the first 12 months, without a supporting analysis sustaining this assumption,

- For time in-default greater than 12 months, the methodology followed is not the same or similar to the one underpinning the estimation of LGD on non-defaulted exposures, since a realised LGD for defaulted exposures at facility level for each reference date is not calculated. The EAD and the total recoveries at each reference date are calculated in an aggregated manner for each pool and year, not ensuring a realised LGD with a floor of 0%,

- As evidenced in the calculation of the LRA LGD for non-defaulted exposures, the use of a scenario that historically considers a credit sale at reference date 72 months does not take into account all observed costs and recoveries and generates a double counting effect of recoveries due to the mixture of scenarios.
In addition, some issues were identified during the implementation of the ELbe estimation process.

For these reasons, the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out in this finding, since the Supervised Entity used an inadequate methodology to estimate the ELbe.","O19.a","The Supervised Entity shall have an ELbe and LGD in-default estimation methods aligned with the ones used for estimating LGD on non-defaulted exposures, e.g. realised LGDs for defaulted exposures should be calculated for each exposure, taking into account the information on the time in-default and recoveries realised so far. ","1",,,"1",,,"The Supervised Entity shall apply a multiplication factor of 1.20 to its estimates for the LGD for defaulted exposures of the housing loans portfolio under the scope of this Decision.

IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433","3/23/2022 05:00 PM","Supervisor","DRG",,,"IRB","LGD","Crédito Habitação","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","F23","Incompleteness of the MoC framework
The MoC framework presented by the institution is not formalised and lacks in completeness, since:

- Not all possible deficiencies related with the estimation of the parameter are identified and analysed, namely, i) methodological deficiencies and, ii) missing or inaccurate data for the calculation of economic loss,

- As the description of the methods for quantification are only described at a very high level, the methodology for quantification of MoC per category is only possible to understand using the supporting files, even though the support files lack adequate organisation and context and include information that is not possible to trace independently and that is contradictory between sources,
- The quantification of the final MoC and in particular the aggregation of MoC A, B and C are not defined,
- The principles for monitoring estimation errors in order to accommodate the correction of errors and uncertainties are not prescribed,
- No action plan is defined in order to rectify the identified data and methodological deficiencies as well as the other sources of additional uncertainty.

Moreover, the adjustments and/or MoCs are quantified based on the restricted population used to estimate the DT LGD, such that the final MoC encompasses the uncertainties stemming from the DT LGD estimation but not the uncertainties stemming from the LRA LGD estimation.","O20","The Supervised Entity shall improve the MoC framework applied to LGD models in order to ensure that it is complete, comprehensive and overarching.
This framework shall contain
i) a process to identify all sources of uncertainties in the estimation of the risk parameters;
ii) a description of the methods to quantify MoCs per category and the final MoC;
iii) the principles for monitoring estimation errors; and
iv) a defined action plan to rectify the identified data and methodological deficiencies as well as the other sources of additional uncertainty.

The quantification of each MoC per category shall cover the uncertainties stemming both from the LRA LGD and the downturn adjustment.",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","6/23/2023 04:00 PM","Final",,"Concluída","4222000000332",,"6/30/2022 12:00 AM","20220630_IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433_Quarter_StatusPoint_JST feedback.xlsx

IMI-2020-PTBES-0178433","3/23/2022 05:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","Crédito Habitação","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F24","Deficiencies in the LGD MoC quantification
On the quantification of the adjustments and MoCs under category A, the following deficiencies were detected:

- The relative impact calculation of increase in defaults due to intra-month T01 trigger default events, of +5.21%, is inappropriately calculated over a population that is not suitable for that purpose,

- For the variation in costs due to the inclusion of the scenario of recurrent sales at month 72 in the estimation, costs were increased in 1.03% at the expected sale date for each open default, but the default status used was according to a different and inconsistent scenario,
- Not all the situations of uncertainty identified by GVM were quantified as MoC A.
Moreover, on the overall impact of the adjustments and the MoCs, the following was concluded by the AT:

- Except for two pools, the final regulatory LGDs are lower than the DT LGDs before adjustments and MoC, which resulted from the several negative adjustments applied; the institution did not assess and ensure that capital requirements were not distorted.

- The institution’s aggregation technique is not equivalent to adding the sum of MoCs for categories A, B and C on top of the DT LGD parameter after applying all the adjustments.","O21","The Supervised Entity shall apply and document adequate methodologies to estimate the appropriate MoC adjustments for all material sources of uncertainty identified in the estimation process of risk parameters for each pool (including the ones identified by the validation function i.e the use of proxy for the determination of cashflow related to interest becoming due and the insufficiencies in cost information related to credit recovery and property management), in order to achieve the most accurate estimates possible.

Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall add the final MoC to the best estimate of the risk parameter and shall ensure that the estimates of the risk parameters and the resulting own funds requirements are not distorted by the necessity for excessive adjustments.","2",,"1","1",,,,"Risco Médio","2/29/2024 04:00 PM","Final","1","Concluída","4222000000333","(31/03/2023) To Started.

(27/01/2025) - In 2021, the GVM issued a recommendation (MM353) for the implementation of a data quality report that would ensure the monitoring of indicators and inputs to the CI model. This recommendation was, however, suspended due to its similar effects to another determined by the DAI (measure MM554) within the scope of the IRB Audit Review of 2023. Considering that the effects of the DAI recommendation did not translate into results in line with those anticipated in the GVM recommendation, it is proposed to reopen its effects by altering the terms and scope of its recommendation and establishing a new implementation deadline. Thus, the following wording for the recommendation and deadline is proposed:
Recommendation: Creation of a report for the monitoring and tracking of input indicators to the CI model in line with the guidelines of the ECB Guide to IM and ECB Guide to RDARR.
Deadline Propose: 31 December 2025.

365,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","F1","Deficiencies in the PD model calibration documentation and lack of in-house knowledge over the PD model calibration exercise
Pursuant to 144(1)(e) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 “the institution documents its rating systems and the rationale for their design and validates its rating systems”

Pursuant to Article 175(1) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 “The institution shall document the design and operational details of its rating systems”. The documentation shall provide evidence of compliance with the requirements in this Section, and address topics including portfolio differentiation, rating criteria, responsibilities of parties that rate obligors and exposures, frequency of assignment reviews, and management oversight of the rating process.

Pursuant to Article 175(4)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 “Where the institution employs statistical models in the rating process, the institution shall document their methodologies. This material shall: (a) provide a detailed outline of the theory, assumptions and mathematical and empirical basis of the assignment of estimates to grades, individual obligors, exposures, or pools, and the data source(s) used to estimate the model;”

Pursuant to Article 175(5) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 “An institution shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the competent authority that the requirements of this Article are met, where an institution has obtained a rating system, or model used within a rating system, from a third-party vendor and that vendor refuses or restricts the access of the institution to information pertaining to the methodology of that rating system or model, or underlying data used to develop that methodology or model, on the basis that such information is proprietary.”

The Supervised Entity does not fulfil the above outlined legal requirements because the documentation provided for the PD Model calibration of LDP and RE rating systems is insufficient and does not describe the main assumptions and underlying rationale. It does not allow a qualified third party to clearly understand the approaches and processes followed during development phase. More specifically:

- The documentation is misleading regarding the calibration approach followed for Project Finance, as all documentation leads to an approach based on the calculation of Long Run Average Default Rate (LRAvDR) and

following alignment to the Average PD of the portfolio, however, the calibration for this rating system is then based on a mapping to the rating scale used by an External Credit Assessment Institution (ECAI).
- The iterative approach followed in the calibration process to assign a PD at grade level is confusing and incomplete.

- The documentation lacks in rationale for i) some fundamental assumptions, as for the treatment applied to the forborne obligors, and ii) the underlying assumptions over some support analysis provided, as for example, based on documentation it is not clear if the analysis over the choice of the non-overlapping approach for the observed one-year default rate (ODR) calculation is properly performed.
- There is no specific change policy in place for models developed by third parties.
Moreover, the Supervised Entity has evidenced a poor level of in-house knowledge of fundamental methodological approaches and assumptions over the PD re-calibration exercise under review.

During the course of the investigation phase, in the several interactions between the Assessment Team and the Supervised Entity, most answers provided by the Supervised Entity were unclear, poorly supported and contradictory to written answers provided in weekly requests, which reveals a lack of proper oversight of the outsourced activities.","O1","The Supervised Entity shall improve the documentation regarding the PD calibration of models Core Corporate, Acquisition Finance, Project Finance, Financial Institutions and Municipalities (LDP) and Real Estate templates and projects (RE), in order to allow a qualified third party to understand the methodology and assumptions and to replicate the model development and implementation. The documentation shall correctly reflect the methodological approach followed, shall be complete and unambiguous. Furthermore, it shall provide a rationale for the assumptions in the methodology.

In case the Supervised Entity intends to describe the fundamental calibration methodology in a separate and overarching framework document, it shall amend the version delivered during the investigation (“202111_Calibration_Framework_LDP_RE_vD.pdf”) according to the obligations in this decision by ensuring it provides insights in the fundamental methodological principles. For this, the Supervised Entity shall enhance the description of the methodologies considered and of the instances when each methodology shall be used. The calibration framework document shall contain clear metrics, thresholds, significance levels and predefined actions during the calibration process. Furthermore, it shall unambiguously define the approach to be followed for the calculation of the long-run average default rate, the criteria for the selection of the calibration function and the treatment to be applied to overrides, outdated ratings and non-rated obligors in future calibration exercises.","5",,"1","5",,,"The Supervised Entity shall apply a multiplication factor of 1.10 to the risk weighted exposure amount (RWEA) for the obligors under the scope of the PD models Core Corporate, Acquisition Finance, Real Estate templates and Real Estate Projects for the purposes of determining the own funds requirements. This limitation is based on the findings underlying Obligation 1 and Obligation 9 as described in Annex IV and shall apply until the ECB has confirmed in writing that this obligation has been fulfilled by the Supervised Entity.","Risco Severo","3/31/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","004222000000418","(20/04/2023)
Alterado o deadline de implementação para 31/10/2025 conforme o plano IRB de 20 de janeiro de 2023. Contudo, RE tem apenas deadline para 31/03/2026.
(3/10/2023) The deadline extension request submitted by the institution was approved under ECB Decision ECB-SSM-2023-PTNOB-11",,,"6/30/2022 06:18 AM","1/23/2025 08:02 AM"

Moreover, it was evidenced a lack of follow-up by the development team to the development process, having the main challenge to the PD model calibration development exercise been performed by the Model Validation Office (Gabinete de Validação de Modelos – GVM) in several parts of the process, in particular to the reference data set (RDS) construction, data cleansing process, LRAvDR calculation.","O2","The Supervised Entity shall maintain an appropriate level of in-house knowledge and core competences, to properly identify, manage and monitor the risks connected to the internal models within the LDP and RE rating systems. 367,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F3","Lack of analysis supporting the mapping between internal and external grades

The Supervised Entity establishes a direct mapping between internal and external rating grades from S&P, for Project Finance, Municipalities and Financial Institutions. However, the mapping chosen approach is not supported by:

- A comparison of internal rating criteria with the criteria used by S&P. Therefore, differences between the external and internal rating criteria were not analysed and documented. For example, for Project Finance, new cut-offs based on the ones defined for the Core Corporate portfolio were applied, which changes the internal rating criteria in comparison to the external rating criteria.
- A comparison of the internal and external ratings through a common obligor analysis, and, in this sense, did not take into account their representativeness for the application portfolio.
