370,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F6","Insufficiencies in the calculation of one-year default rates and lack of clear data cleansing procedures
The calculation of one-year default rates presents the following deficiencies:

- Considers obligors that do not have a credit obligation at the beginning of the one-year observation period, this is, exposures with no credit risk product (obligors with no on-/off-balance exposure which appear in the sample because they are in a group of companies, of which at least one other legal entity has a free limit, and obligors with documentary credit notified);

- The Supervised Entity does not take into account overrides, when assigning the obligors to grades for the purpose of the one-year default rate calculation. For calibration purposes, considering that an approach using LRAvDR at portfolio level is used, the methodology process applied would lead to less conservative PD estimates at grade level if overrides were taken into account. Nevertheless, the Supervised Entity was not able to support through back testing analysis, that the PD estimates at grade level are conservative enough since all back testing analysis were performed without overrides.

- The Supervised Entity did not analyse if the migrations to different rating grades, rating model or rating system within the observation period bias the default rate and if an appropriate margin of conservatism (MoC) adjustment should be considered.

The Supervised Entity evidences a lack of clear data cleansing procedures, as a good understanding over the appropriateness of the risk-modelling data and a proper data quality assessment of observations with very low exposures was not provided.

Moreover, some inappropriate data treatment assumptions are applied to non-rated obligors that affect ODR calculation and the calibration process, leading to an increased uncertainty of the risk quantification, namely:
- Obligors with outdated ratings: it is assigned the previous rating assigned to the obligor, irrespective of the date of the last rating, with a CAP on B- for LDP and CCC+ for RE;
- Unrated obligors: it is assigned a risk grade of B- to LDP and CCC+ to RE.","O4","The Supervised Entity shall ensure within the calculation of the one-year default rates that:

(i) The denominator only consists of non-defaulted obligors with any credit obligation observed at the beginning of the one-year observation period and therefore excludes those non-defaulted obligors without any credit obligation (i.e. without any on- or off-balance sheet exposure) at the beginning of the one-year observation period;
(ii) Overrides are taken into account at the beginning of the one-year observation period, when assigning the obligors or exposures to grades;

(iii) An appropriate analysis is provided on whether migrations to different rating grades, rating models or rating systems or sales of credit obligations bias the default rate and, if so, reflect through an appropriate adjustment and consider an adequate MoC;

(iv) No data treatments are applied to obligor information (e.g. data treatments to obligors with outdated ratings or to non-rated obligors), in order to provide a meaningful differentiation of risk and accurate and consistent quantitative estimates of risk.

Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall demonstrate to have a good understanding over the appropriateness of the risk-modelling data, by having in place a process for vetting data inputs into the model, which includes an assessment of the accuracy, completeness and appropriateness of the data.","5","1","5",,,,,"Risco Alto","3/31/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","004222000000422","(20/04/2023)

371,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F7","Deficiencies in the process to derive relevant drivers for risk quantification
In the calibration segmentation analysis, the Supervised Entity did not properly assess if the following subsets of obligors have a different risk level:
- Obligors whose obligations stem solely from non-credit products, and;
- Obligors only with committed but undrawn credit lines.

In the specific calibration segments for RE rating system, the Supervised Entity chose to use the combination of two risk drivers, rating template and credit policy, however, no analysis over the joint effect of the risk drivers in order to validate the appropriate level of the final segmentation was performed.

In addition, the Supervised Entity evidences an inconsistent approach for the selection of calibration segments, since the criteria for identifying the calibration segments may vary depending on the rating system under analysis. The definition of a material calibration segment is not established, which allows the Supervised Entity to define materiality in an arbitrary manner.","O5","The Supervised Entity shall define the calibration segments based on a proper assessment of all relevant drivers of risk to ensure a grouping of sufficiently homogeneous exposures. The approach for the selection of relevant calibration segments shall be clearly documented and consistently applied across the different rating systems. For each rating system, the final decision regarding segmentation for calibration purposes shall be substantiated and validated.","3",,"2","2",,,,"Risco Alto","3/31/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","004222000000423","(20/04/2023)

372,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F8","Inaccurate process of selecting calibration segments for the Real Estate rating system

The Supervised Entity has defined for the RE rating system a calibration segment, namely the non-standard (NSTD) credit policies, that is not representative in the application portfolio. The three segments for non-standard evidence concentration issues, namely, segment real estate investment (REI) NSTD has four populated grades; real estate development (RED) NSTD has four populated grades, with almost 100% of exposure concentrated in one rating grade (LCCC); RE Projects NSTD has four populated grades, with circa 85% of exposure in rating grade CCC. Moreover, all non-standard calibration segments evidence issues in risk differentiation, as demonstrated through AUC and Gini metrics.

According to the Supervised Entity, non-standard obligors are expected to have a higher level of risk, therefore it is not comprehensive that better PD’s are assigned to these obligors than the ones assigned to standard obligors, although in some rating grades the cut-offs applied over the scores are different. Also, for REI NSTD and real estate investment smaller (REIS) NSTD, the proposed PD’s for rating grades AAA to A+ are non-compliant with regulation, as the minimum requirement of 0.03% is not applied. Nevertheless, no obligor falls within these rating grades in the application portfolio as of December 2020.

In this sense, the calibration segments defined do not provide a meaningful differentiation of risk and accurate quantitative estimates of risk, for the RE rating system.","O6","The Supervised Entity shall review the calibration segments for the RE rating system. It shall ensure that the segmentation provides for a meaningful differentiation of risk and for accurate, consistent and intuitive PD estimates that are in line with the perceived level of risk and that are compliant with the regulation.","1",,,"1",,,,"Risco Médio","3/31/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","004222000000424","(20/04/2023)

373,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","DRG",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F9","Lack of conservative measure of risk for non-rated obligors in model application

Pursuant to Article 144(1)(h) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, institutions shall demonstrate to the satisfaction of the competent authority that the following standards are met: the institution has assigned and continues with assigning each exposure in the range of application of a rating system to a rating grade or pool of this rating system.

Pursuant to Article 171(2) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, institutions shall take all relevant information into account in assigning obligors and facilities to grades or pools. Information shall be current and shall enable the institution to forecast the future performance of the exposure. The less information an institution has, the more conservative shall be its assignments of exposures to obligor and facility grades or pools. If an institution uses an external rating as a primary factor determining an internal rating assignment, the institution shall ensure that it considers other relevant information.

Pursuant to Article 174(c) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, institutions that use statistical models and other mechanical methods to assign exposures to obligors or facilities grades or pools, shall meet the following requirements: the data used to build the model shall be representative of the population of the institution's actual obligors or exposures.

The Supervised Entity does not fulfil the above outlined legal requirements because in the model application the Supervised Entity is proposing to apply a specific treatment to the non-rated obligors, by applying:
i) for unrated of Core Corporate, Project Finance, Municipalities and Financial Institution models, a fixed rule of B-;
ii) for unrated of RE rating system, a fixed rule of CCC+.

All proposed treatments for non-rated obligors do not allow for a conservative measure of risk, as the worst performing rating grade is not assigned. Additional uncertainty deriving from the treatments applied to outdated and unrated obligors are not covered with an appropriate MoC.

Moreover, it is evidenced that for the Core Corporate portfolio, the proposed rating grade for non-rated obligors, B-, has an estimated PD lower than the observed LRAvDR for these type of obligors.","O7","The Supervised Entity shall ensure that the obligors under the scope of the LDP and RE rating systems are timely rated.

In exceptional cases, when it is not possible to assign a rating, a conservative approach to allocate PDs should be developed and applied.",,,,,,,"The Supervised Entity shall apply the PD of the worst performing rating grade to non-rated obligors under the scope of the PD models Core Corporate, Acquisition Finance, Project Finance, Financial Institutions, Municipalities, Real Estate templates and Real Estate projects used for the calculation of risk weighted exposure and expected loss amounts.

This limitation is based on the finding underlying Obligation 7 as described in Annex IV and shall apply until the ECB has confirmed in writing that this obligation has been fulfilled by the Supervised Entity.","Risco Médio","10/31/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Concluída","004222000000426","(14/03/2023) - Atualizado conforme presente no Workflow de Melhoria Incremental

(14/04/2023) - The rule applicable to unrated obligors should be clearly outlined in the overarching rating documentation. We expect Novo Banco to provide the relevant internal methodologies before closing this obligation.

374,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F10","Inappropriate treatment over the forborne obligors

375,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F11","Deficiencies in the calibration methodological approach

Pursuant to Articles 144(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “the institution's rating systems provide for a meaningful assessment of obligor and transaction characteristics, a meaningful differentiation of risk and accurate and consistent quantitative estimates of risk;”

Pursuant to Articles 174(e) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, if institutions use statistical models and other mechanical methods to assign exposures to obligors grades, institutions shall document how human judgement and model results are to be combined;

Pursuant to Article 175(4), where institutions employs statistical models in the rating process, institutions shall document their methodologies, providing a detailed outline of the theory, assumptions and mathematical and empirical basis of the assignment of estimates to grades.

Pursuant to Article 180(1)(h) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, the “length of the underlying historical observation period used shall be at least five years for at least one source. If the available observation period spans a longer period for any source, and this data is relevant, this longer period shall be used”.
The Supervised Entity does not fulfil the above outlined legal requirements because the overall calibration process presents the following weaknesses:

- The full historical observation period was not assessed in order to properly conclude over a representative mix of good and bad years, as the year 2010 was not considered in the presented analysis; Moreover, no analysis was performed to properly justify the exclusion and lack of assessment over the years prior to 2010 from the LRAvDR calculation;

- The Supervised Entity defined cut-offs to be applied over the Project Finance rating system, however, the human judgment used for this assumption is not properly documented; no underestimation is foreseen as the cut-offs are always in the sense of downgrading;
- In the bucketing process, the forborne obligors are excluded of the process to define the score cut-offs;

- The non-rated obligors are considered in the Bayesian rescaling assigned to a specific rating grade, according to the rules defined for non-rated obligors. This assumption leads to less conservative PD estimates;
- The proposed treatment by downgrading the rating grades of forborne obligors in the calibration leads to less conservative PD estimates;

- The iterative approach to obtain the PD estimates at grade level, considers two steps with the execution of tests in order to stop the iteration process. However, the Supervised Entity only executes the tests for the final step, which is for the PD with MoC. No tests were performed to ensure an alignment of the LRAvDR with the PD without MoC;

- Some statistical tests are wrongly executed (for example, LRAvDR calculated assuming a 0% DR in years with no observations) and some defined tests are not executed at all (for example, homogeneity test for CC and the comparison to check if LRAvDR is smaller than regulatory PD at grade level);

- Several tests performed in the final step of the calibration iterative process do not present satisfactory results and a proper justification was not provided in order to accept and override the test results In some rating grades, it is observed LRAvDR above the regulatory PD. Moreover, the chosen thresholds in the back-testing and quality assurance tests do not ensure that appropriate actions are followed.","O9","The Supervised Entity shall improve the calibration process, by:
(i) Assessing properly the full historical observation period (covering also years prior to 2010) and adequately documenting and justifying the final time period selected;
(ii) Documenting and properly supporting all expert assumptions;
(iii) Considering in the bucketing process all facilities under scope;
(iv) Not considering non-rated obligors in a specific rating grade;
(v) Not applying treatments that influence the rank ordering of obligors, as was performed for forborne obligors; (vi) Applying a calibration methodology before the application of MoC;
(vii) Ensuring statistical tests are correctly executed;

(viii) Defining thresholds for statistical tests that trigger appropriate actions. Moreover, all conclusions and rationales over statistical results should be properly justified.","8",,"4","8",,,"The Supervised Entity shall apply a multiplication factor of 1.10 to the risk weighted exposure amount (RWEA) for the obligors under the scope of the PD models Core Corporate, Acquisition Finance, Real Estate templates and Real Estate Projects for the purposes of determining the own funds requirements. This limitation is based on the findings underlying Obligation 1 and Obligation 9 as described in Annex IV and shall apply until the ECB has confirmed in writing that this obligation has been fulfilled by the Supervised Entity.","Risco Severo","3/31/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","004222000000428","(20/04/2023)

376,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","F12","Incomplete MoC framework and deficiencies in the MoC quantification
The MoC framework lacks in terms of completeness, since:
- For the quantifications, the methodological principles are described in a very simplified manner not being possible to fully understand the quantification methodology for MoC A, B and C;
- The quantification of the final MoC, namely the aggregation of MoC A, B and C is not clearly defined;

- The principles for monitoring estimation errors in order to accommodate the correction of errors and uncertainties are not prescribed. Moreover, no procedures are defined to address the need to develop an action plan in order to rectify the identified data and methodological deficiencies as well as the other sources of additional uncertainty.
In terms of application of the MoC framework, the following issues are evidenced:

- For MoC A, not all possible deficiencies related to the estimation of the parameter are identified and analysed, for example the potential bias stemming from the choice of non-overlapping approach to calculate the average of ODR and inaccurate rating assignment (impossibility of using rating grade overrides) that is input to the overall calibration process;
- MoC B is not quantified in a consistent manner for all rating systems;

- Despite the inclusion of alternative methods to quantify MoC C, only the results for “Binomial Confidence Level” approach were provided, without any justifications or results for the other approaches, being, in that sense, impossible to compare its better fitness.

The descriptions of the underlying methods are insufficient (e.g. application of Bayesian adjustment to extrapolate MoC effects at grade level) being only possible to understand them through supporting files.","O10","The Supervised Entity shall ensure its Margin of Conservatism framework to apply to LDP and RE PD models is complete, comprehensive and overarching. This framework shall contain:
(i) detailed methodological principles, as well as the definition for aggregating MoC A, B and C;
(ii) the principles for monitoring estimation errors;
(iii) a clear action plan to rectify the identified data and methodological deficiencies as well as the other sources of additional uncertainty.

The Supervised Entity shall ensure that all possible deficiencies related to the estimation of the parameter are identified and analysed and that all quantifications are well executed and described.","4",,"1","4",,,,"Risco Alto","3/31/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","004222000000429","(20/04/2023)

378,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GVM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","F14","Insufficiencies and inconsistencies regarding the validation framework
The validation framework proposed by the Supervised Entity for the LDP and RE PD rating systems presents the following weaknesses:
- Template Mercados is not included in the list of templates to be validated in the scope of LDP models, even though its outcome is considered an internal rating;
- It is not foreseen a deep review of procedures for data collection and data cleansing of the construction of the RDS;

- The initial validation proposed for LDP is not comprehensive enough in the case of changes to the ranking scoring method (new or revised templates). For instance, it is not foreseen analysis to the discriminatory power at the level of individual risk factors or other possible segments such as modules nor benchmarking analysis;
- The calculation of default rates in the annual validation exercises is defined to follow an overlapping approach, which is not aligned with the calibration methodology (non-overlapping approach);
- It is not foreseen any analysis regarding overrides to inputs of HDP or LDP rating systems;
- It is not foreseen an assessment to the adequacy of the prudential treatment applied to non-rated exposures and outdated ratings in HDP and LDP rating systems;

- Thresholds to assess the same metric are defined inconsistently in different sections for the validation type benchmarking and credit assessment, such as: i) percentage of cases where internal ratings are expected to match external ratings (30% versus 35%); ii) percentage of cases where internal ratings are expected to deviate from external ratings by 1 notch maximum (mentioned in page 144 but not in page 194);

- It is not clear in the Supervised Entity's current policies nor in the validation framework whether any model change to LDP or RE templates proposed by the third party vendor should be discussed and validated by GVM, in order to decide on its implementation;

- No tests are explicitly foreseen to assess predictive ability in initial validation, both in the case of LDP and HDP.","O12","The Supervised Entity shall ensure a complete and appropriate validation framework for LDP and RE PD models by:
(i) Including template “Mercados” in the scope of all validation activities to LDP models;
(ii) Foreseeing a deep review to data collection and data cleansing procedures related to RDS construction;
(iii) Clarifying and enhancing the analysis foreseen in initial validations to changes in the ranking scoring method (new or revised templates);
(iv) Ensuring consistency in the calculation of default rates in the annual validation with the calibration methodology applied by the Supervised Entity (non-overlapping approach);
(v) Analysing overrides to inputs (applicable also to high default portfolios);
(vi) Ensuring that non-rated exposures and outdated ratings are subject to adequate prudential treatment (applicable also to high default portfolios);

(vii) Ensuring consistency in the thresholds presented throughout the validation framework for the several metrics; (viii) Foreseeing tests to assess predictive ability in initial validations (applicable also to high default portfolios);
(ix) Enhancing the analysis performed to quantification and application of MoC;
(x) Confirming the regulatory framing and the plans for future implementation of any model changes proposed by the development team.

Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall ensure that any model change to LDP or RE templates proposed by the third-party vendor is discussed and validated by the validation unit in order to decide on its implementation.
Following up on the exchanges below regarding obligation 12 of IMI 4783, we agree to close this obligation under the following conditions:

v) GVM will enhance its validation framework on the components related to rating assignment and model usage of Medium Enterprises models within the same timeframe foreseen to the implementation of Obligation #12 of the IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908 (August 2023).

379,"IMI-2021-PTBES-0176908","1/13/2022 04:00 PM","Supervisor","GVM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F15","Incompleteness of the validation exercise
The validation exercise performed over the PD calibration of LDP and RE presented the following insufficiencies:

- Not all the relevant topics were fully and critically assessed by GVM, such as: i) existence of several obligors with very low exposure amounts; ii) treatment of obligors with only committed but undrawn credit lines; iii) adequacy of the treatment applied to forborne and non-rated obligors; iv) RDS construction; v) time horizon analysis performed only with DR of rated obligors; and vi) extrapolation of conclusions taken on the Core Corporate portfolio to Real Estate rating system, such as the appropriateness of the non-overlapping approach and the adequacy of the adjustment to the S&P calibration function to account for differences in the definition of default;
- No assessment was performed to the quantification and application of MoC;
- Regulatory framing of the calibration approach proposed was not checked;

- Some methodological weaknesses identified by GVM are not clearly stated in the findings raised. For instance, the inclusion of non-rated obligors in the calibration of rated obligors and the lack of clear assessment regarding the insufficiencies covered or not covered by MoC;
- There is no clear linkage between the analysis presented in the validation reports and the findings raised;
- There is no evidence that GVM was fully aware and had discussed with the development team the future implementation of the calibration proposed;

- The calibration framework submitted for approval was not reviewed by GVM.","O13","In future validation exercises for material model changes, the Supervised Entity shall ensure that all methodological weaknesses identified by the validation unit are mentioned in the findings in a clear manner. Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall ensure a clear linkage between the analysis presented in the validation reports and the findings raised (e.g. adding to each supporting analysis in the validation report a reference to the related findings, if any). (28/01/2025) - reaberta com a emissão do relatório GVM 278 2025 - Apresentado no CMA 103: In 2021, the GVM issued a recommendation (MM353) for the implementation of a data quality report that would ensure the monitoring of indicators and inputs to the CI model. This recommendation was, however, suspended due to its similar effects to another determined by the DAI (measure MM554) within the scope of the IRB Audit Review of 2023. Considering that the effects of the DAI recommendation did not translate into results in line with those anticipated in the GVM recommendation, it is proposed to reopen its effects by altering the terms and scope of its recommendation and establishing a new implementation deadline. Thus, the following wording for the recommendation and deadline is proposed:
Recommendation: Creation of a report for the monitoring and tracking of input indicators to the CI model in line with the guidelines of the ECB Guide to IM and ECB Guide to RDARR.

This recommendation was, however, suspended due to its similar effects to another determined by the DAI (measure MM554) within the scope of the IRB Audit Review of 2023. Considering that the effects of the DAI recommendation did not translate into results in line with those anticipated in the GVM recommendation, it is proposed to reopen its effects by altering the terms and scope of its recommendation and establishing a new implementation deadline. Recommendation: Creation of a report for the monitoring and tracking of input indicators to the CI model in line with the guidelines of the ECB Guide to IM and ECB Guide to RDARR.

406,"PTNOB_2021_ICAAP","8/30/2022 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DPGC",,,"ICAAP",,"Todos os Segmentos","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","2.1","Novo Banco’s definition of internal capital includes some components that are doubtful to be available to cover risks within a 12-months period under a conservative approach that is deemed adequate under the economic perspective according to the ECB guide. More specifically, these components are the “CCA Available” and future expected profits in 2022 that are based on the budget assumptions:

(1) - The CCA available of EUR 485 million cannot be considered as economically available capital due to the uncertainty of its actual payment, especially in a 12-months’ time horizon. During 2021 several developments occurred leading to significant doubts on the eligibility and timing of future claims under the CCA as regulatory capital of Novo Banco. The JST communicated to Novo Banco that CCA claims no longer comply with the conditions set out in Article 26(1) of the CRR and, consequently, should not be recognised as CET1 items for the purpose of the own funds calculation until the respective CCA payment occurs.6 Likewise, any future claim on the CCA cannot prudently be considered economic capital. Novo Banco partly acknowledges this as it has also included a perspective of the economic surplus without the CCA (surplus of EUR 48 million over capital requirements, but deficiency over the management buffer of EUR 201 million) but only as an informative item.

(2) - Novo Banco adjusts its capital supply in the economic perspective with the MTP’s expected profits for 2022 (EUR 335 million). These profits are based on optimistic assumptions when the ICAAP was approved and including them as internal capital cannot be considered conservative or prudent as set out in principle 5 of the ICAAP guide. A sufficiently conservative projection could be the adverse scenario included in the MTP, which projects a loss in 2022. Given that the ICAAP is produced in the beginning of the second quarter, however, it could be acceptable to include any net profit generated in the first quarter in the capital supply in the ICAAP.","2.1","Novo Banco’s definition of internal capital should include only components that are available to cover risks within a 12-months period under a conservative approach that is deemed adequate under the economic perspective. As such, components such as future CCA claims and forecasted year-end profits are not to be included, unless they are sufficiently certain or already occurred and thus compatible with the economic perspective’s prescribed conservativism. Moreover, Novo Banco should analyse and document the eligibility to cover risks for each component of internal capital, taking into account the economic value considerations and continuity assumption.",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"Foi decidido no CMA de dia 21/09/2022 que as medidas relativamente ao ICAAP não iriam ser todas monitorizadas pelo presente comité. 415,"PTNOB_2021_ICAAP","8/30/2022 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG",,,"ICAAP",,"Todos os Segmentos","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","4.3.1","The stop-loss limit for the investment portfolio, being lower compared to the SVaR7, determines the bank’s internal capital for market risk of the investment portfolio. However, Novo Banco has breached its internal limits substantially and extensively since the first quarter of 2022. This lack of limit discipline shows that the approach for setting the economic capital in line with the internal limits is not adequate. In fact, Q1 2022 has shown that the critique made by the OSI team in 2019 – that capital requirements based on stop-loss limits don’t reflect true potential risk under finding 12b of the ICAAP OSI – is substantiated by a real-life example.","4.3.1","Instead of using the stop-loss limit to determine its internal capital as currently done, the bank should consider alternative approaches, also to cater for the known deficiencies of the institution’s current use of additive models which prompt Novo Banco to use the stop-loss limits.",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"At least in the past ICAAP submissions. The bank calculates economic capital as the lower of a) the stressed VaR (SVaR) based on historical simulations over 20 years with a 99.9% confidence level and a holding period depending on the liquidity; and b) the stop-loss limit as set out in the risk appetite framework plus activation or transaction costs.

As there is a considerable difference between the spread regime on the ICAAP’s reference date and the credit spread regime of stressed period due to the near default situation of Portugal the additive models, in practice, transpose to the reference date the credit spread movements that happened when Portugal almost went bankrupt and had a very different starting rating. These limitations of the used additive model should be addressed. This could be done, for instance, by using government curves aligned with the currency and rating of the issue in the reference date while considering the effect of the one-year migration risk aside; or with hybrid models that combine additive shocks with multiplicative shocks (for example, a DHS model).

417,"PTNOB_2021_ICAAP","8/30/2022 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG",,,"ICAAP",,"Todos os Segmentos","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","4.3.3","The treatment of holding periods (HP) is not in line with the ICAAP’s time horizon of the economic perspective which is one year. The HP is meant to reflect the liquidity level of a position, i.e. the capability to unwind – sell or hedge – the position in a stressful situation. However, the allocation of the economic capital in line with the losses occurred during the HP – if below one year – for the selected historical date is not prudent. It assumes that the position is fully liquidated, or hedged, at the end of the HP but does not determine what would trigger the initiation of this unwinding process – hence the start of the HP when the decision is made to unwind the position. For example, the HP of a certain position be 10 days and the SVaR be computed based on the losses accumulated in the worst 10-day period of the selected historical stress period. Novo Banco would then allocate only this SVaR as its economic capital to the position. However, if the same stress period occurred in the future it is unclear at what point in time Novo Banco would take the initiative to unwind the positions, particularly when they are not loss making at the point of the decision (which could happen and is part of the diversification assumption, see below). Realistically, a liquidation is only going to happen once the position has already accumulated some losses which are, however, not capitalised because they are not considered in the historical stress observation. If the positions are not loss making it seems unrealistic that they are assumed to be liquidated during the HP and – without being liquidated – they can thus still accumulate losses which are not capitalised.

On the same token, even if the positions were liquidated before one year as the bank assumes, NB does not clarify what it does with the generated funds after the liquidation. The bank currently assumes that if a period of stress happens, it would sell everything and keep only cash (in case of liquidating the positions). However, if NB acquired other bonds to replace the previous ones, it would have to assume risks that need to be capitalised.

With respect to the holding periods, please note the following statement from the ECB report on banks’ ICAAP practices 2020 guide (p.55): 9 Another modelling assumption that raises concerns are inadequate holding periods applied to market risk exposures, which in most cases are lower than 250 trading days, with ten days’ holding period being the most frequent assumption. While banks are generally free to choose any holding period, periods that are shorter than the general risk horizon imply the far-reaching strategic decision being taken that the bank would close its market risk exposures and not re-open positions until the end of the general risk horizon, once losses, quantified for the holding period, had materialised. Inadequate holding periods, therefore, lead to a blurred view of risks and can pose a threat to economic capital adequacy.

Against the above, the critique on the HPs is also applicable to the SVaR hypothetical backtesting which only tests for the duration of the HPs.","4.3.3","Novo Banco should revise its treatment of the holding periods that are below the general risk horizon of one year. In particular, it should also consider in its economic capital (as well as in the theoretical backtesting) the losses that trigger the liquidation process of the positions with holding periods below one year. If positions are liquidated before one year, Novo Banco has to hold additional capital for the reinvestment of the funds resulting from the liquidation, or state that it would close its market risk exposures and not re-open positions until the end of the general risk horizon. For this, as stated in Recommendation 17.1 of the ICAAP OSI, Novo Banco should provide evidence of suitable procedures or specific rules and controls in place to ensure that the trading desks are closed for the remainder of the year should the P&L limits be reached (this evidence is not set out adequately in the 2021 ICAAP).",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"Foi decidido no CMA de dia 21/09/2022 que as medidas relativamente ao ICAAP não iriam ser todas monitorizadas pelo presente comité. Apenas medidas pontuais com envolvimento direto da área de modelos iriam ser monitorizadas","9/21/2022 12:00 AM",,"9/16/2022 08:43 AM","3/14/2024 07:58 AM"

418,"PTNOB_2021_ICAAP","8/30/2022 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG",,,"ICAAP",,"Todos os Segmentos","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","4.3.4","Treatment of stop-loss limits when determining the historical stress period: There is an inconsistency when calculating the stop-loss per calendar year in the actual risk management (i.e. starting from 0 in each calendar year10), whereas the historical stress period is based on a trailing 12 months period. For example, if a stress period spans two calendar years, the allocated internal capital is based on the overall stop loss limit allocated for one calendar year (e.g. EUR 150mn for the investment portfolio) while the stop loss limit is reset to 0 at the beginning of each new year. In a worst case, this can lead to losses almost double as much as the internal allocated capital.

Furthermore, when using stop-loss limits as an alternative to the SVaR methodology (which as stated above is not prudent), the decision to unwind the positions is usually only made when the red, or at least the amber limit, is breached and losses have already accumulated. The subsequent process of unwinding would imply the holding periods that Novo Banco identified for each position and would thus extend the accumulated losses over the holding period beyond the stop-loss limit. Otherwise, it cannot be explained why a stressed position – after accumulating losses to the extent the stop-loss limit is breached – can be sold right away with merely some stop-loss activation costs, while in the SVaR methodology holding periods are introduced based on “the feasibility to sell the assets in the short-term”. On the same token, the stop-loss limit activation costs Novo Banco considers are not realistic in times of severe stress and do not consider fundamental things like concentration of positions.","4.3.4","Ensure that the stop-loss limit across calendar years is treated consistently in the risk management and internal capital allocation process; consider also the losses over the holding period of the different assets after the stop-loss limits have been breached and the positions need to be liquidated, as well as the concentration of positions.",,,,,,,,"Risco Alto","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"See NB’s reply to JST SREP questions related to market risk from 25 February 2022, p. 25.

428,"ECB-SSM-2021-PTNOB-7 / TRIM 3974","3/12/2019 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GVM",,,"IRB","PD","Grandes Empresas e Institucionais","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","F13","Flaws identified regarding previous recommendations issued by the validation unit

The 2016 validation report included 5 recommendations regarding the LDP portfolio. Subsequently, in the 2017 validation report, 2 of those recommendations were classified as implemented. However: a) No robust evidence has been presented demonstrating that a full compliance has been achieved regarding those recommendations related with the negative results on the backtesting and methodology and application components of specific templates. b) Regarding the recommendation to establish a framework of monitoring of rating systems, the Supervised Entity classified it as implemented based on the approval of the governance framework alone. However, the Supervised Entity still lacks a formal monitoring policy and recurrent monitoring exercises, conditions which were not highlighted in the validation reports issued after 2016. There are significant flaws in the follow-up of previous recommendations from the validation unit. (10/05/2024) - Relativamente ao registo 104223000000014, informa-se que foi apresentada a prorrogação da data objetivo, em CAE de 17/04/2024, para 31/12/2024

(07/01/2025) - Medida implementada a aguardar validação do detetor. No comite de modelos 101 realizado a 20-12-2024 foram aprovados os novos parametros IFRS9 apos as correções dos findiings identificados pelo GVM na decorrencia do seu processo de validaçao inicial. No especifico dos modelos LGD por não estarem ainda totalmente documentados e fechads foi aprovado uma MOC de 15% até parecer positivo final do GVM sobre parametros propostos os quais se propos serem apresentados até final de 1º trimestre de 2025. Estes trabalhos serão alavancados nos processsos iRB, sendo que para os segmentos de CH e SME Retail o GVM já se pronunciou que entendem existir conservadorismo dos parametros face ao historico recente de LGD realized e cenários de estabildiade nas projeções FW. De referir que o atraso na validação dos LGD não foi responsabilidade do GVM o qual teve de se focar na reavalidação dos modelos de PD após a correção dos findings que identificou na 1º validação. Este processo foi acompanhado e decido quer em CMA, quer em steering de IFRS9.
Os relatórios de validação encontram-se partilhados na pasta GVM-DAI/validação_IFRS9/2024

IMI-2022-PTBES-0195861","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Crédito Consumo","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","4","Shortcomings in the analysis and treatment of the grade assignment dynamics of the PD models.

The GAD assessment was not performed for the final grades of the models and consequently does not allow to analyse/understand the volatility of own funds requirements. Moreover, the assessment performed at scoring model level has the following issues:
- There is no rationale to merge the output scoring of two different origination models (clients and non-clients) in order to create the grades for the GAD assessment.
- The assessment based on migration matrices is considering only one observation (03/2011) and is not taking into account the whole calibration period.

- It was not fully verified that the dynamics underlying the grade assignment reflect risk over two- or three-years’ time horizon. Although one migration matrix has been verified for longer time horizon, the other two analyses of ratios performed by the SE were considering only 1 year horizon. Thus, the cyclicality analysis (via DR, PD or Discriminatory power) is not performed on longer time period for GAD purposes.

- The institution has not performed any analysis of chosen rating philosophy taking into account the design of risk drivers, thus was not able to justify that selected model design is giving an appropriate balance between drivers that are predictive only over a short time horizon and drivers that are predictive over a longer time horizon.

IMI-2022-PTBES-0195861","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Crédito Consumo","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","6","Insufficiencies in the PD model calibration framework and its application.

The calibration framework is very generic and does not sufficiently detail the analyses to be carried out in each dimension and how the results of the different approaches should be considered. In particular:

- For the analysis of the correlation between the macroeconomic variables and one year default rates, it is not detailed which input data (time period) should be considered for the correlation analysis and how the results from different correlation tests should be combined.
- It is not described the approaches considered to classify the historical period in terms of good and bad years, nor how the results of different methodologies should be considered and compiled.
- No threshold was defined for an appropriate mix of good and bad years and consequently is not defined what results would lead to triggering additional inclusion of new periods.

- It is not clear at which level the minimum of 7 risk grades should be ensured (portfolio, model scope, risk differentiation segment, PD calibration segment). - It is not defined the criteria to select the most adequate bucketing approach.

- There is no sufficient detail regarding the tests to be applied (at each level) and how its thresholds should be considered based on the different samples used. Moreover, the thresholds are not clearly defined (for example, for HHI, both a 15% limit as well as 25% limit are mentioned).

- No differences are prescribed for the GAD assessment between behavioural and origination models even though some analysis have no rationale for origination models. Additionally, the framework does not clearly define in what phase of the calibration process the GAD should be performed and how the results of these analyses allow to understand the volatility of own funds requirements.
The AT identified the following shortcomings in the PD calibration exercises:

- The institution did not analyse if the migrations to different rating grades, rating model or approach to calculation of capital requirements within the observation period bias the default rate and if an appropriate MoC adjustment should be considered.

- It was not well justified the reasons to have unscored facilities in an automatic model and it was not analysed if this bias de default rate of the remaing grades, not having be calculated an appropriate MoC adjustment.
- There are differences in the historical information of the macroeconomic variables for the same period between the analysis performed for origination and behavioural models.

- Different approaches were used to calculate the correlation between ODR and macroeconomic variables across origination and behavioural models (yearly and quarterly macroeconomic data, respectively) without an appropriate justification.
- It is not clear the macroeconomic variables selected as the most correlated with the ODR considering the results of different approaches tested for the correlation.

- The analysis of the period representative of the variability of default rates were limited to the current scoring model and new DoD data,therefore not ensuring that a sufficient number of bad years is represented in the data from 2010 onwards, and is not clear why 2010 was not included for origination;

- No bucketing was tested for the calibration segment “restructured loans” of origination PD model.","2","The Supervised Entity shall clearly define and document the PD calibration framework. This framework shall contain sufficient detail regarding the analyses to be carried out in each dimension and how the results of different approaches shall be considered.

The PD calibration framework shall contain a description of all the tests to be performed and the minimum thresholds to be met for each metric defined. Furthermore, it shall set out the data sources and the reference time periods to be considered.
Furthermore, the PD calibration framework shall define that as part of the PD calibration exercises the Supervised Entity shall:
i) ensure that all the elements set out in the framework are comprehensively and consistently executed;

ii) analyse whether the migrations to different risk grades, scoring model or approach to calculation of capital requirements within the observation period introduce a bias to the default rate and accordingly determine when a MoC adjustment shall be considered;

iii) justify the reasons for unscored facilities and assess whether those introduce a bias to the default rate of the remaining grades.","7",,"2","7",,,,"Risco Médio","7/27/2024 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Validação Detetor","4223000000475,00","(31/08/2023) - Novobanco is already reviewing the calibration framework and will take into account and accomodate all topics covered within this obligation.

IMI-2022-PTBES-0195861","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Crédito Consumo","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","7","Insufficiencies in the PD MoC framework and its application.

The chapter of the calibration framework specific to the MoC calculation cannot be considered a complete MoC framework, since it does not define robustly the underlying procedures for the identification and documentation of deficiencies as well as for the quantification and monitoring of the estimation errors. In particular the following insufficiencies were identified:
- The general formulas defined to quantify the MoC A and B are not sufficient detailed to be replicated by a qualified third party and do not prevent to have negative values for MoC.
- The statistical analyses defined for calculation of MoC C is not detailed enough and there are no criteria defined to choose the final statistical method.
- It is not defined in the MoC framework how the adjustments and MoCs should be aggregated to achieve the final PD estimates.
- There is no procedure defined to monitor the insufficiencies identified.
As a consequence of the lack of detail of the framework, the following shortcomings were identified: - There are negative values of MoC A being applied in the origination PD model.

- There are errors in application of the Adjusted variation of LRA parameter in case of origination model for segment “Clients more than 2 holders”. - MoC B for behavioural PD model was calculated on top of MoC A and MoC C.

- The relative adjustment for MoC B is calculated at aggregated level without justifying that the uncertainty represented by relative adjustments is not significantly different across PD grades towards this MoC.
- There are analyses prescribed in the framework to calculated MoC C that were not performed and there is no support for the approach selected.
- The MoC C approach applied does not capture the serial corelation of the monthly one-year default rates.

- The MoC C was not calculated using the best estimates of the risk parameter, rather the LRA DR prior to adjustments.","3","The Supervised Entity shall improve its MoC frameworks for PD and LGD to make it complete, comprehensive and overarching. The MoC framework shall address all the deficiencies outlined in Finding 7 and Finding 11 in Annex III and shall include at least:
i) robust procedures for the identification and documentation of deficiencies;

ii) a clear definition of the methods for the quantification of each MoC and the final MoC. In addition, MoC C shall always be greater than zero, whereas MoC A and MoC B shall be equal to or greater than zero;
iii) the principles for monitoring estimation errors; and
iv) details regarding what should be included in an action plan to rectify identified data and methodological deficiencies leading to MoCs as well as the other sources of additional uncertainty.

The Supervised Entity shall ensure that all possible deficiencies related to the estimation of parameters are identified and analysed, and that all quantifications are well described and executed accordingly.","6",,"1","6",,,,"Risco Médio","7/27/2024 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Validação Detetor","4223000000476,00","(31/08/2023) - Novobanco will review the MoC framework and accomodate all feedback received concerning this topic. The institution does not allocate direct costs at facility level, considering a proxy to estimate all costs. The costs related to the personnel responsible for credit sales were not included in the approach followed. In the EAD calculation, the institution included any write-offs that occurred previously to the default date, regardless of being related with the default event or not. The identification of restructuring events is performed by proxies that lack a common understanding between the different stakeholders, which leads to differences between the development and the validation teams. Additionally, when the total amount of the restructured facilities is lower than the total amount of the restructuring facilities, there is loss of information from the RDS. Furthermore, the institution was unable to provide evidence that the events detected by the proxies were indeed restructuring events which leads to uncertainty on their correct identification. For the cases that return to non-default status the institution is considering the exposure at the date of return to non-default status as the amount of the artificial cash flow. IMI-2022-PTBES-0195861","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","N/A","Crédito Consumo","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","11","Incompleteness of the LGD MoC framework and insufficiencies in the MoC quantification.
The MoC framework presented by the institution is not formalised and lacks in completeness, since:

- The description of the methods for quantification are only described at a very high level, thus, it was not possible for a third knowledgeable person to independently understand the MoC quantifications and reasoning. -- The quantification of the final MoC and in particular the aggregation of MoC A, B and C are not defined.
- The principles for monitoring estimation errors in order to accommodate the correction of errors and uncertainties are not prescribed.
- No action plan is defined in order to rectify the identified data and methodological deficiencies as well as the other sources of additional uncertainty.

Moreover, the institution has not identified the need for a MoC B despite the structural changes occurred in the recovery processes over the years observed in the RDS. Instead, an adjustment for the DT LGD estimation was performed based on these structural changes, which led to a DT LGD with an implicit MoC B. Thus, a MoC B is not added on top of the estimated DT LGD. Finally, MoC C was calculated using the LGD estimates before adjustments (instead of the best estimate LGD) and considering the long-run period (instead of downturn period).

,3","The Supervised Entity shall improve its MoC frameworks for PD and LGD to make it complete, comprehensive and overarching. The MoC framework shall address all the deficiencies outlined in Finding 7 and Finding 11 in Annex III and shall include at least:

ii) a clear definition of the methods for the quantification of each MoC and the final MoC. In addition, MoC C shall always be greater than zero, whereas MoC A and MoC B shall be equal to or greater than zero;
iii) the principles for monitoring estimation errors; and
iv) details regarding what should be included in an action plan to rectify identified data and methodological deficiencies leading to MoCs as well as the other sources of additional uncertainty.

IMI-2022-PTBES-0195861","3/31/2023 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GVM",,,"IRB","Framework","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","13","Insufficiencies in the validation framework.
The validation framework for high default portfolios presents insufficiencies in terms of initial  nd recurrent validation.
The insufficiencies regarding initial validations are:
- There is no guidance or template to perform the assessment of regulatory compliance.
- The overall validation conclusion is derived based on qualitative assessment, which does not ensure consistency in the outcome.
- There is no clear list of tests and analyses that should be done for PD calibration and at which level they should be performed.

- It is not clear which tests are blocking, if any, nor how the results of the several tests should be combined. - The analysis of discriminatory power at the level of risk differentiation function is not clearly foreseen.
- The description of the validation process to a LGD model change is very broad and only provides general guidance on the aspects that should be covered.

- The validation of LGD model does not foresee any quantitative test to predictive ability and discriminatory power. Other analyses such as representativeness, stability and data cleansing are also not explicitly covered.
The insufficiencies regarding the recurrent validation are:
- It is not defined which time horizon should be considered in the analysis of discriminatory power of the risk differentiation function, which might lead to inconsistent outcomes.

- Inconsistent course of action foreseen when any sub-model (e.g. PD origination for new clients) presents a discriminatory power below the internal threshold and the overall model (e.g. PD origination) is above the applicable threshold.
Additionally, the insufficiencies applicable to both the initial and recurrent validations are:

- It is not defined the level at which homogeneity, heterogeneity, granularity, concentration and discriminatory power should be assessed when analysing the PD rating scale, e.g. at the level of the calibration segment, risk differentiation function or rating system. Although the validation framework contains some general statements, it is not enough to ensure clarity.
- The formula to compute metric HHI adjusted is not defined.

,4","The Supervised Entity shall enhance its validation framework to ensure that it covers all relevant aspects of its rating systems and that a qualified third party understands the rationale for the validation opinion. In particular, the framework shall address the deficiencies outlined in Finding 13 in Annex III. For both the initial and the recurrent validation, the framework shall include at least:
i) guidance or templates to perform the assessment of regulatory compliance;

ii) an outline of the aspects and tests to be analysed, a description of all the validation tests to be performed, a definition of the level at which the validation tests are to be calculated, the data sources to be used and the time horizon to be considered;
iii) the minimum thresholds to be met for each of the quantitative tests;

iv) the approach to combine the results of the several aspects analysed, both quantitative and qualitative, into the final validation opinion.","6",,,"6",,,,"Risco Alto","7/27/2024 12:00 AM","Final",,"Concluída","4223000000477","(31/08/2023) - Novobanco will continue to enrich the content of its validation framework in line with regulatory determinations and expectations. To this end, novobanco will facilitate clarification meetings with the JST, if necessary, to ensure that the understanding of the required changes is in line with the objectives intended by the supervisor.

A definição do processo e responsabilidades associadas à atribuição de ponderações aos cenários macro econónmicos será incluída na norma de imparidade de forma a endereçar as recomendações do Auditor Externo.

De modo a incorporar a informação forward looking nos parâmetros de risco, o Grupo, tem como base as projeções macroeconómicas desenvolvidas pelo DTF – Economic Research. Uma das funções deste departamento, independente do Departamento de Risco Global (DRG), é a de desenvolver projeções macroeconómicas para 3 cenários diferentes: base, adverso, e favorável, aos quais é necessariamente associada uma probabilidade de ocorrência para efeitos de estimação de perdas por imparidade.

Com referência a dezembro de 2022, o Grupo atualizou os cenários macroeconómicos considerados para estimação dos parâmetros de risco.

Tendo em consideração o contexto de degradação das principais variáveis macroeconómicas, o Grupo considerou, através de expert judgement, a necessidade de incorporar um ajustamento às Default Rates projetadas, tendo em consideração que os valores obtidos após a atualização das projeções macroeconómicas não apresentavam razoabilidade económica dado que o Grupo considera um histórico longo de taxas de juro reduzidas e o modelo apresentou-se muito sensível a variações significativas da taxa de juro (Euribor 3M). Adicionalmente foi necessário ajustar o anchor point (2018 a 2022) tendo em conta o período histórico considerado nos parâmetros de risco.
Neste contexto, o Banco aplicou dois ajustamentos com base em expert judgement:
a)
column2: Aplicou um cap às Default Rates projetadas, limitando-as à Default Rate máxima verificada no histórico considerado (desde 2010).

column1: b)
column2: Foi aplicado um floor às Default Rates projetadas, considerando o valor mínimo entre a Default Rate projetada após atualização das projeções macroeconómicas e a Default Rate projetada para o mesmo período com referência a 31 de dezembro de 2021.

column1: Sem prejuízo de verificarmos que o histórico da Euribor a 3 meses considerado pelo Grupo apresenta valores muito próximos de 0 que podem tornar o modelo demasiado sensível a variações significativas no indicador macroeconómico, não concordamos com o racional dos ajustamentos aplicados.

O Grupo aplica um ajustamento às taxas de recuperação estimadas (TREs) de cada período, como forma de alisar as recuperações que se estimam ocorrer no futuro. Este alisamento consiste em distribuir por períodos anteriores uma parte da recuperação que se estima ocorrer em períodos posteriores.

Dado que as recuperações estimadas são descontadas temporalmente no processo de cálculo de imparidade e não no desenvolvimento do parâmetro, este ajustamento tem impacto direto na imparidade pois há montantes de recuperação que estão a ser descontados por menos períodos do que aqueles que o modelo de estimação do parâmetro prevê.

513,"GVM 183b-2023-IRB.PD_RE","5/23/2023 12:00 AM","CM","DRG",,,"IRB","PD","Real Estate","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","1 ","Incorreta aplicação de PD no cálculo de RWA para as situações de projectos imobiliários que sejam sujeitos a

aplicação de overlay de RED.","1","Assegurar a correção, a tempo da implementação da nova calibração, da atual incorreta aplicação de PD no cálculo de RWA para as situações de projetos imobiliários que sejam sujeitos a aplicação de overlay de RED.",,,,,,,,"Risco Médio","8/31/2023 12:00 AM","Final",,"Concluída",,"Entrando no último ponto da OT, tomou a palavra o GVM para apresentar as principais mensagens da Validação Recorrente de 2023 ao Modelo IRB de PD de Real Estate.  Começou por referir que, embora o banco tenha já aprovado pelo BCE uma nova calibração para o modelo, uma vez que a mesma ainda não se encontra implementada, os resultados da validação e o reporte ao BCE foram realizados tendo em conta a antiga calibração. No entanto, para permitir comparabilidade, todas as análises foram realizadas segundo as duas abordagens distintas: a antiga calibração, ainda em uso, e a nova aprovada em implementação. Neste âmbito, resultados quantitativos negativos obtidos na validação da “antiga” calibração que não se verifiquem com a “nova”, foram derrogados por avaliação qualitativa da validação.

Como primeira mensagem, o GVM afirma que não há alteração relevante dos indicadores de acompanhamento.  O resultado global deste exercício de validação é verde por razões de derrogação qualitativa dado que os resultados quantitativos negativos da atual calibração são confortavelmente melhorados pela nova calibração, aprovada em 2022, e que se encontra em fase final de implementação. O GVM salientou a evolução positiva do nível de incumprimento e perfil de risco da carteira de RE, da boa capacidade discriminante do modelo, e da adequação da nova calibração em termos de poder preditivo.

No follow-ups de recomendações e ações anteriores, o GVM salientou que no Plano Operacional para a revisão integral do sistema IRB, prevê que a nova calibração seja implementada até 19 de agosto de 2023, mas que os novos modelos de RE apenas serão revistos até março de 2026, facto ainda dependente da aprovação do regulador.

Em relação à análise de contexto, o GVM realçou que o mercado imobiliário continua com uma tendência ascendente, embora se observem algumas descidas no último trimestre de 2022. Para além disso, e de acordo com indicadores da EBA, o GVM afirma que o crescimento do setor imobiliário se encontrava globalmente sustentado a nível europeu, demonstrando um contexto globalmente positivo, quer no segmento Comercial Real Estate quer no segmento Residential Real Estate.

Relativamente à evolução da carteira, o GVM refere que há uma forte redução até ao ano de 2015, justificando o mesmo pela transição dos contratos para NPLs. Ainda sobre as características da amostra, e tendo em consideração uma visão global a dezembro de 2022, o GVM dá nota de 41 clientes que apresentavam exposição superior a 10M€, num total de 1.133M€, representativos de 63% da carteira de Real Estate.

Foi destacada a situação de ainda existirem clientes na carteira com exposição muito baixa, muita das vezes relativa a pequenos juros corridos, facto que enviesa o número real de clientes do banco para efeitos de calibração, embora a maioria seja unrated.  A este propósito, PSL do DRG comentou que, na sua opinião, deveria haver uma medida estrutural no Banco para  compreender e endereçar estas situações de saldos muito pequenos, e que o DRG que tem um finding e uma obligation para contemplar esta situação.

Quanto aos defaults observados no período de validação, à semelhança do referido na validação de LDP, o GVM voltou a realçar que, à semelhança do observado em LDP, existem defaults ocorridos que estão incorretamente classificados por UTP por trigger manual (T07), quando na verdade se trata de decisões do CIA e como tal deveriam ter sido classificados como UTP por imparidade (T02). Foram ainda evidenciados: o facto de 4 dos 7 defaults decorreram do reconhecimento em default de exposições em garantias emitidas sobre clientes com pouco ou nenhuma relação comercial do banco, e que não pagavam comissões há vários anos, situação que o DRT informou ser não genérica. CCO considerou esta situação imaterial em Real Estate, porque não contaminar a eficiência do modelo. No entanto, o DRG afirma que pode contaminar a calibração ao nível do portefólio, recomendando acompanhamento.

Relativamente à série histórica de incumprimento e relação com a PD, o GVM afirma que é visível uma mudança a partir do ano de 2015, sendo notório que, desde aquela data, a PD se encontra muito acima da DR, e por este motivo, considera que o modelo está a ser penalizado devido ao seu histórico, independentemente da abordagem utilizada.

O GVM apresentou as análises relativas à concessão de moratórias e ao efeito de eventuais carências de capital, com as quais concluiu que nenhuma das situações teve influência no reduzido número de defaults observado. Estas conclusões, complementadas pelo facto de o contexto económico ser positivo, como já mencionado, leva à conclusão de que o ano em análise foi verdadeiramente bom, e não influenciado por outros fatores mitigantes.

Foi também apresentada e discutido a representatividade e influencia nos resultados apurados e da operação Crow de venda de NPA do próprio Banco e com financiamento ao comprador.  Neste contexto, foram identificados 30 clientes, dos quais 23 anteriormente notados por outros modelos e com vários ratings, para os quais o DRT atribuiu agora o rating de b5 no âmbito da operação Crow, situação que reforça significativamente a concentração neste rating. O DRT esclareceu que o risco deixou de estar limitado ao valor dos ativos do mutuário, mas ao mix do portfolio do comprado, sendo que o Banco pode acionar, para além dos ativos, também o fundo. O Rui Fontes afirmou que, no essencial, a situação em questão seria semelhante à aplicável como se fosse um grupo económico.

Por último, o GVM informou ter identificado uma situação de incorreta aplicação de PDs no cálculo de RWAs. Mais concretamente, o GVM identificou que, com a calibração atual ainda em utilização, os projetos imobiliários com overlay de RED estão a ser notados com a PD da escala de RED e não de Projetos Imobiliários, situação que se considera incorreta. A implementação da nova escala de RE deverá acautelar os procedimentos que garantam a correta afetação da PD a projetos que sejam objeto de overlay Parent Sub, recomendação que o DRG tomou nota no presente CMA.

Como recomendação para o futuro, o CRO solicita que sejam separados e apresentados os slides mais importantes para discussão em CMA, devendo todo o restante relatório ser remetido para anexo, facilitando a apresentação em CMA.
Com a nova calibração de RE este tema deverá ficar resolvido mas aguardamos confirmação da sua efetiva correção

528,"Revisão Modelo CH CMP - Risco Clientes ENI v1.0","9/30/2023 12:00 AM","CM","DRG",,,"IRB",,"Crédito Habitação Comportamental","Em Produção","Deficiência de Data Quality",,"Data Event - Falhas nas alocações de contratos a imóveis",,,,,,,,,,"Risco Baixo",,"Final",,"Cancelada",,"(15/09/2023) Verifica-se um aumento expressivo do número de observações em fev/22 e a ordem de grandeza mantém-se elevada até ao término do ano. Estes aumentos não são acompanhados por evidentes incrementos na dimensão de contratos no portfólio, pelo que O DRG efetuou uma análise casuística para despistar o motivo de tais ocorrências. Esta análise concluiu que contratos associados a um mesmo imóvel em jan/22 e, portanto, avaliados num mesmo processo, passam a estar, a partir de fev/22, associados a múltiplos imóveis.  Foi criado um Data Event para reportar esta situação embora não tenha sido possível, até ao momento da elaboração do presente relatório, apurar o que efetivamente sucedeu.
Medida cancelada por ser redundante com  a medida 529, trata-se de um data event identificado pelo DRG em termos semelhantes ao identificado pelo gvm no relatorio GVM 201B.

column2: Revisão dos IA’s de Real Estate, que de momento a equipa associada a este segmento de risco encontra-se fortemente dedicada à auditoria OSI realizada pelo Banco Central Europeu. Paralelamente, a mesma equipa reúne esforços para a atualização dos ratings dos clientes que lhes estão afetos no sentido de alcançar o nível de coberturas consentâneo com o realizado nos últimos anos. Assim sendo, solicita-se a compreensão dos diversos intervenientes do Comité de Modelos no sentido de ser estendido o prazo para concluir esta tarefa por mais um ou dois meses.

column1: Foi ainda referido que o estudo que está a ser realizado pelo Carlos Andrade está concluído com base em valores anuais obtidos de diversas fontes de informação. No entanto, para que se obter um resultado mais fiável e o mais atual possível, estão a ser realizados contactos com a Informa DB para incluir na análise valores mensais de diversos indicadores, e assim ter um resultado o mais próximo da realidade. Neste contexto, o DRT solicitou que o prazo de apresentação deste estudo ao CMA fosse estendido por mais um més.

(06/02/2024) o DRT propôs no CMA nr. 89 que os IA de ‘Real Estate Investment’ e ‘Real Estate Development’ se mantenham inalterados nesta fase e sejam reanalisados em Comité de Modelos no prazo de 6 meses.

(10/03/2025) A 13/02/2025 (conforme o e-mail anexado - ""FW planos de Ação e evidências de resolução Findings ModelMate - Lote 2""), foi solicitado o seguinte ""Solicita-se que se encerre este finding com base na MoC que foi incluída no modelo de LGD CH. Num próximo processo de desenvolvimento de modelo de LGD, a metodologia de alocação será revisitada. (...) este finding deveria ter sido fechado, pois a metodologia de alocação de custos em LGD CH é a posteriori à de LGD SME."".
Resposta do GVM: O finding 542 refere-se à necessidade de se reapreciar/rever a metodologia de alocação de custos indiretos, tendo por base as conclusões do relatório de validação.

Como é sabido, os modelos de LGD IRB devem incorporar na estimação de parâmetros quer os custos diretos quer os custos indiretos. Até ao momento, o GVM ainda não considerou suficiente e adequada qualquer metodologia apresentada para alocação de custos indiretos nos modelos IRB. Esta situação tem sido temporariamente endereçada através da aplicação de MoCs específicas nos parâmetros finais. Importa referir que a aplicação de MoCs não corrige o problema na sua base, apenas mitiga as suas consequências. Lembrar também que a obligation 4 da IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651 determina a necessidade de revisão do modelo de custos indiretos até à data 21/10/2026. Independentemente do modelo de LGD, a metodologia de custos indiretos deve ser independente e aplicável a todos.",,,"11/3/2023 03:00 AM","3/14/2025 08:03 AM"
543,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0232715","10/19/2023 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","StartUps, Enis e Municipalities","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","1","Insufficiently detailed PPU policy

According to Article 149(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, an institution shall demonstrate, when requesting to revert to the standardized approach, that the use of the standardised approach is not proposed in order to reduce the own funds requirement of the institution, is necessary on the basis of nature and complexity of the institution's total exposures of this type and would not have a material adverse impact on the solvency of the institution or its ability to manage risk effectively.

To ensure the Supervised Entity applies a consistent approach in defining the treatment (SA/IRB) of its exposures, the Supervised Entity should have a more detailed PPU policy that allows it to decide in an objective manner which portfolios should be in SA or IRB. The current PPU policy lacks:
i) a clear definition of a non-material business unit / portfolio,
ii) clear criteria to identify, for LDPs, when the modelling effort is prohibitive and the portfolio needs to be treated with the SA,
iii) clear criteria to assess the proportionality of the development costs of models;

iii) for the non-material business unit / portfolios, clear criteria on which ones should be reverted to SA.","O1","The Supervised Entity shall ensure it has a comprehensive policy to decide which exposures should be treated with IRB and which exposures with the Standardised Approach (SA) for the calculation of own-funds requirements for credit risk. This policy should contain objective criteria to avoid room for interpretation and to ensure it is applied consistently.

To this end, the Supervised entity shall enhance its current PPU policy to include more objective criteria to decide when a portfolio should be treated with the IRB or SA, in particular, the policy should include:
i) a clearer definition of a non-material business unit or portfolio;
ii) clearer criteria to identify, for LDPs, when the modelling effort is prohibitive and the portfolio needs to be treated with the SA;
iii) clearer criteria to assess the proportionality of the development costs of models;

iii) for the non-material business unit or portfolios, clearer criteria on which ones should be reverted to SA.",,,,,,,,"Risco Médio","4/19/2024 12:00 AM","Final",,"Concluída","4223000000517","(31/03/2024) - De acordo com o Quarter status point, o DRG referiu que a documentação da revisão da política está em validação, será apresentada no CMA de Abril de 2024.

578,"Relatório do Auditor Externo sobre o processo de quantificação de imparidade da carteira de crédito (Dez 23)","12/31/2023 12:00 AM","Auditor Externo","DRG","DRG Gestão Planeamento da Qualidade do Ativo",,"IFRS9",,"Todos os Segmentos","Em Produção","Governance","C.13","Insuficiência no processo de governance dos add-ons.

De forma a incorporar no modelo de cálculo de imparidade do Grupo fatores de risco adicionais que não se encontram refletidos no referido modelo, o Grupo registou, com referência a 31 de dezembro de 2023, um conjunto de ajustamentos fora da máquina (add-ons) cujo montante total ascende a aproximadamente 70 milhões de euros. Estes ajustamentos são apresentados e aprovados ao nível do comité de risco do Grupo.

Considera-se que o nível de documentação suporte à estimativa dos add-ons constituídos é insuficiente, inclusivamente na medida em que o detalhe apresentado ao nível dos comités de risco não permite compreender com total clareza o racional para a quantificação do add-on relativo às contingências para condições de mercado adversas, que ascende a 29 milhões de euros sobretudo no que respeita a uma componente do ajustamento que ascende a 13 milhões de euros.

Não foi elaborado um documento metodológico ou memorando que explicitasse o racional por detrás da metodologia definida para quantificar as potenciais insuficiências do modelo de cálculo de imparidade do Grupo, não estando desta forma formalmente definidos:
i) os pressupostos considerados para quantificação dos add-ons;
ii) metodologias alternativas;
iii) os perímetros de consolidação e segmentos afetados pelas insuficiências do modelo; e

iv) o cenário macroeconómico sobre o qual o add-on se encontra a ser definido e as respetivas limitações do modelo sobre as quais o Grupo identifica uma necessidade extraordinária de quantificar perdas.

Sem prejuízo da documentação subsequente partilhada pelo Grupo para justificar a estimação do montante em questão, conforme mencionado anteriormente, é no âmbito dos Comité de Risco que os referidos add-ons são apresentados e aprovados, pelo que se considera fundamental que a informação transmitida nesse âmbito permita às funções de gestão compreender o contexto, metodologias e implicações dos add-ons constituídos.

Adicionalmente, à exceção do ajustamento referente à atualização dos cenários macroeconómicos, verificou-se que o montante de imparidade não alocada foi apenas registado na entidade Novo Banco sendo que, para as restantes entidades pertencentes ao perímetro do Grupo, expostas ao mesmo contexto macroeconómico, não foi registado qualquer montante. Relativamente ao ajustamento referente às contingências do Decreto-Lei 91/2023 que visa refletir o aumento de risco ao nível do portfolio de CH, o Grupo deveria ter calculado a componente do add-on a alocar ao NB Açores, uma vez que a carteira de CH do NB Açores também é abrangida pelo cenário definido pelo Grupo. Adicionalmente, no âmbito do add-on referente às condições macroeconómicas adversas, que visa refletir a deterioração creditícia das exposições dos segmentos de empresas que não são captadas pelo modelo do Grupo, todo o montante do add-on foi somente alocado à entidade Novo Banco.","C.13","Recomendamos que o Grupo robusteça o seu processo de governance associado à estimação e registo de imparidade não alocada, procurando reforçar a documentação apresentada em Comité de Risco para aprovação, procurando que a mesma reflita de forma clara o racional, metodologia de estimação, entidades e segmentos afetados.","1",,"1","1",,,,"Risco Médio","12/31/2024 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Validação Detetor","4224000000553","(12/04/2024) Esta medida está em draft decision até o relatório de imparidade de 2023 ser final.

Relativamente ao ajustamento referente às contingências do Decreto-Lei 91/2023 que visa refletir o aumento de risco ao nível do portfolio de CH, o Grupo deveria ter calculado a componente do add-on a alocar ao NB Açores, uma vez que a carteira de CH do NB Açores também é abrangida pelo cenário definido pelo Grupo. Adicionalmente, no âmbito do add-on referente às condições macroeconómicas adversas, que visa refletir a deterioração creditícia das exposições dos segmentos de empresas que não são captadas pelo modelo do Grupo, todo o montante do add-on foi somente alocado à entidade Novo Banco.
