No âmbito do desenvolvimento do parâmetro da PD para efeitos de cálculo de capital, o Grupo realizou um processo de re-rating/recalibração das curvas PD, aos segmentos de Low Default Portfolios e Real Estate. O processo de re-rating resultou que para uma mesma pontuação o rating atribuído ao cliente se alterasse. Uma vez que, para estes segmentos, a curva de IFRS9 a aplicar depende do rating atribuído, as curvas de IFRS 9 deixaram de refletir o nível de risco correto das exposições destes segmentos, tendo sido necessário realizar um ajustamento às curvas PDs de IFRS9 no último trimestre de 2023.

O processo de atribuição de rating apresenta um carácter manual o que tornou operacionalmente impossível a aplicação do novo rating a todos os clientes tendo o Banco optado por priorizar os clientes mais materiais. Nesse sentido, com referência a 31 de dezembro de 2023 o Grupo apresenta em carteira exposições do mesmo segmento com escalas de rating distintas para efeito de atribuição do parâmetro PD.
O Grupo, de forma a estimar as novas curvas IFRS 9 a aplicar a estes segmentos teve de se basear num conjunto de pressupostos julgamentais, tendo em consideração que:
1. Não existe uma transposição direta entre os segmentos de IRB e as curvas de IFRS 9;
2. O processo de re-rating incluiu a definição de novos segmentos de calibração;
3. Existem diferenças em termos da composição dos segmentos entre IRB e as curvas IFRS 9;
4. As curvas PDs de IFRS 9 para Real Estate incluem vários ratings tendo existido uma redefinição dos segmentos no âmbito do projeto de re-rating;

5. Os ratings atribuídos globalmente aos clientes destes segmentos dependem da ponderação das exposições de cada cliente pelos distintos segmentos, pelo que a alteração das escalas num segmento impacta o rating final do cliente nos restantes.

,,Risco Médio","10/21/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Suspensa",,"(19/06/2024) The proposed grades for both small and medium enterprises models have been tested for homogeneity, but the test performed by the Supervised Entity, both development and internal validation units, based on random sampling within each grade is not fit for this purpose. The test does not consider any risk driver to check if there are subpopulations with different risk profiles. If criteria-based subpopulations are considered, e. g., separating the populations that are scored by different branches of the model (according to turnover and seniority), many grades do not pass the homogeneity test. 592,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Pequenas e Médias Empresas","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","2","Lack of comprehensive grade assignment dynamics analysis.
The Grade Assignment Dynamics (GAD) assessment was not performed for the final grades of the models and
consequently does not allow to analyse/understand the volatility of own funds requirements. Moreover, for medium
enterprises, no assessment was performed in the calibration exercise under assessment.
The assessment performed for the small enterprises portfolio presents the following shortcomings:
- Although the framework stipulates that the rating migration should be analysed for each phase of the economic
cycle (expansion or recession), only one position, the worst point of the cycle (04/2012), was considered as
starting point, and only migrations from that point to other bad or neutral years were contemplated. Furthermore,
the statistical comparison between the BoY and EoY populations, set out in the framework, was not performed;

593,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Gestão de Informação de Risco e Infraestrutura","GDM","IRB","PD","Pequenas e Médias Empresas","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","3","Deficiencies in the PD Quantification
Pursuant to Article 174(e) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, if institutions use statistical models and other mechanical
methods to assign exposures to obligors grades, institutions shall document how human judgement and model results
are to be combined, while pursuant to Article 175(4), where institutions employs statistical models in the rating process,
institutions shall document their methodologies, providing a detailed outline of the theory, assumptions and mathematical
and empirical basis of the assignment of estimates to grades.
Pursuant to Article 179(1)(d) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, the population of exposures represented in the data used
for estimation, the lending standards used when the data was generated and other relevant characteristics shall be
comparable with those of the institution's exposures and standards. The economic or market conditions that underlie the
data shall be relevant to current and foreseeable conditions. The number of exposures in the sample and the data period
used for quantification shall be sufficient to provide the institution with confidence in the accuracy and robustness of its
estimates;
The calculation of one-year default rates presents the following shortcomings:
- For small enterprises, the analyses conducted to support the choice of an overlapping approach are incomplete

and lack justifications. For example, the SE did not evaluate the potential bias introduced by implicitly overweighting the overlapping time period. Moreover, several analyses were conducted to compare the average observed default rates (ODR) obtained from both approaches and no guidance is provided on how third parties
should combine these results.
- For medium enterprises, no analyses were performed to support the choice of an overlapping approach in the
proposed calibration.
- No studies have been performed to check if the substantial credit sales occurred introduce any significant bias
in the ODR calculation.
The PD calibration process presents the following inadequacies:
- The representativeness of historical data against the application portfolio was not properly assessed namely for
the distribution of risk drivers and no analyses were performed to evaluate the representativeness in terms of
the current and foreseeable economic and market conditions. Moreover, for medium enterprises, no analyses
were perform related to changes in the lending standards and recovery policies.
- The Supervised Entity did not fully justify the choice of the set of macro variables nor the respective period
analysed to assess the Likely Range of Variability (LRoV) and why specific macroeconomic variables directly
related to the corporate environment, such as sector or industry-specific indices, were not tested.
- The procedures defined by the Supervised Entity to classify each year as “Good”, “Bad” or “Neutral” and to
assess the proportion of each type in a certain reference period were not consistently applied for the portfolios
under scope. As a result, different conclusions are achieved for the same reference period. Moreover, no
threshold was defined for an appropriate mix of good and bad years and consequently is not defined what
results would lead to triggering the inclusion of additional periods.
- The variability of the observed one-year default rates has not been explicitly assessed neither at calibration
segment nor at rating system level, so it is not clear how such variability supports the choice of the LRoV period
and is not ensured that the worst ODR is included.
- In the calibration segmentation analysis, the Supervised Entity did not properly assess the existence of subsets
of obligors with a different risk level. For example, for small enterprises, the final segmentation was mostly
based on expert judgement and was not properly justified, as there are other exposure thresholds that also led
to distinct risk profiles. Moreover, for medium enterprises, no calibration segment analysis was conducted.
- For small enterprises, the final step of the bucketing algorithm used by the Supervised Entity consists on an
expert-based manual aggregation which does not allow an independent third party to fully replicate it, since it is

not properly documented. Additionally, the automatic part of such algorithm is performed only considering a sample of 70% of the available data and no analysis was perfomed to assess if the sample chosen introduces
any bias on the scale’s cut-off points. For medium enterprises, the bucketing was not revised and is not ensured
that the score cut-offs would not change significantly with the new data considered in this calibration exercise.
The Supervised Entity did not ensure that unrated obligors have a PD at least equal to the worst-performing rating grade.
In light of the above, the ECB concludes that the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out for this
finding because the analysis supporting the overlapping approach for small enterprises is incomplete and lacks justification,
leading to potential bias without clear guidance on result combination. For medium enterprises, no supporting analysis
exists for the overlapping approach in the proposed calibration. The PD calibration process also shows regulatory
inadequacies. The representativeness of historical data against the application portfolio was not properly assessed. The
choice of macro variables and the period analysed for the Likely Range of Variability was not fully justified, and relevant
corporate-specific indices were not tested. Procedures to classify years as “Good,” “Bad,” or “Neutral” were inconsistently
applied, leading to different conclusions for the same period, with no defined thresholds for an appropriate mix of good and
bad years. Moreover, the variability of observed one-year default rates was not explicitly assessed, making the support for
the Likely Range of Variability period choice unclear and not ensuring the inclusion of the worst ODR. The calibration
segmentation analysis did not properly assess subsets of obligors with different risk levels. For small enterprises,
segmentation was based on expert judgment without proper justification, and for medium enterprises, no segmentation
analysis was conducted. The bucketing algorithm for small enterprises involved expert-based manual aggregation, which
is not fully documented or replicable. For medium enterprises, the bucketing was not revised to ensure score cut-offs would
remain consistent with new data. Finally, unrated obligors were not ensured a PD at least equal to the worst-performing
rating grade."," O1 and O2","O1 - The Supervised Entity shall ensure that unrated obligors have a PD at least equal to the worst-performing
PD rating grade.
O2 - The Supervised Entity shall properly document in each calibration exercise the analysis supporting the
choice between an approach based on overlapping and an approach based on non-overlapping oneyear time windows. This analysis shall include at least the items specified in paragraph 80 of
EBA/GL/2017/16 and shall be clear how they contribute to the final choice.
The Supervised Entity shall analyse whether the substantial sales of credit obligations occurred bias the
default rate and, if so, they shall reflect this in an appropriate adjustment and consider an adequate
MoC.
The Supervised Entity shall properly assess the representativeness of historical data against the
application portfolio, in terms of all the items described in paragraph 28 of EBA/GL/2017/16.
The Supervised Entity shall properly justify the choice of the set of macro variables and respective
period analysed to assess the Likely Range of Variability and consider the inclusion of specific
macroeconomic variables directly related to the corporate environment, such as sector or industryspecific indices.
The procedures defined by the Supervised Entity to classify each year as “Good”, “Bad” or “Neutral” and
to assess the proportion of each type in a certain reference period shall be properly documented and

consistently applied. Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall clearly define what considers an appropriate mix of good and bad years and consequently what results would lead to triggering the inclusion of
additional periods.
The variability of all observed one-year default rates of each model in scope shall be explicitly assessed
and concluded upon, being expected that the maximum observed one-year DR is included in the period
defined.
In the segmentation analysis of each calibration exercise, the Supervised Entity shall properly assess
and justify the existence of subsets of obligors with a different risk level.
In each calibration exercise, the Supervised Entity shall document and justify the calibration sample
considered and the process of grouping ranked obligors or exposures to grades. The Supervised Entity
shall find an appropriate balance between the comparability of the calibration sample with the
application portfolio in terms of obligor and transaction characteristics and its representativeness of the
likely range of variability of default rates.

594,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","PD","Pequenas e Médias Empresas","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","4","Insufficiencies in the quantification of MoC
applied to the PD parameters
Pursuant to Article 179(1)(f) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, institutions shall add to its estimates a margin of
conservatism that is related to the expected range of estimation errors. Where methods and data are considered to be
less satisfactory, the expected range of errors is larger, the margin of conservatism shall be larger.
In the application of the Margin of Conservatism (MoC) framework for small and medium enterprises, several
shortcomings have been identified:
- Although the MoC framework stipulates an upper limit at a 90% confidence interval, the Supervised Entity

considered a 95% confidence interval. Moreover, the classification of the deficiencies is not consistent, as the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic is assessed under MoC A for small enterprises and under MoC B for medium
enterprises. Furthermore, other MoC B possible adjustments were not considered for medium enterprises.
- In the case of small enterprises, the adjustment for trigger T01 (Obligations past due) includes obligors outside
the IRB scope for the reference period (January 2020 to May 2020). Additionally, the adjustment is calculated
over a period that is not the the LRoV period and at portfolio level and not at calibration segment level.
Furthermore, the adjustment relies on a limited period without evidence of ongoing deficiency monitoring.
- The deficiencies detected for trigger T04 and T06B have been treated differently for small and medium
enterprises. For the first portfolio, each deficiency was dealt with separately and a respective MoC was
obtained, while for the second these deficiencies are aggregated and a single adjustment and MoC are
quantified without a proper justification for the different treatment. Additionally, the appropriate adjustments for
each portfolio varied regarding these triggers. For medium enterprises, adjustments included a probation period,
whereas for small enterprises, no such period was considered.
- There are several approaches prescribed in the framework to calculate MoC C that were not performed and
there is no support for the approach selected.
Moreover, the MoC C approach applied does not take into consideration the dependency between default rates over time
nor does it account for the fact that the uncertainty associated with the general estimation error is primarily driven by the
statistical uncertainty of each ODR and the length of the time series.
In light of the above, the ECB concludes that the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out for this
finding because several shortcomings were identified in the application of the MoC framework for small and medium
enterprises. The Supervised Entity used a 95% confidence interval instead of the stipulated 90%. Additionally, possible
MoC B adjustments were not considered for medium enterprises. For small enterprises, the adjustment for trigger T01
included obligors outside the IRB scope and was calculated over a non-Likely Range of Variability period at portfolio level
instead of the calibration segment level, relying on a limited period without ongoing deficiency monitoring. Furthermore,
several prescribed approaches to calculate MoC C were not performed, and the selected approach lacked support. The
applied MoC C approach did not consider the dependency between default rates over time or account for the statistical

uncertainty of each ODR and the length of the time series, which primarily drives the general estimation error.","O3","The Supervised Entity shall consistently apply the internally defined MoC framework, properly justifying
and documenting the selected approaches, ensuring that the same deficiencies are considered,
classified, treated and quantified similarly across models. Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall
regularly monitor the levels of MoC applied, confirming that the levels of MoC defined are still adequate
considering the most recent information available. In particular, the adjustment performed regarding
trigger T01 that was calculated using data between January 2020 and May 2020 shall be updated
considering more recent data in order to verify its adequacy.
Furthermore, the Supervised Entity shall account in its MoC C approach for the fact that the uncertainty
associated with the general estimation error is primarily driven by the statistical uncertainty of each ODR
and the length of the time series, taking into consideration also the dependency between default rates
over time.","4","1","1","2",,,"Limitation 1: The Supervised Entity shall apply a multiplication factor of 1.25 (add-on) to its estimates for the PD of small and medium enterprises portfolios
under the scope of this Decision.
The add-on shall be applied for the purpose of calculating RWA and expected loss.

This limitation shall apply until the ECB has confirmed in writing that Obligation 3 has been fulfilled by the Supervised Entity.","Risco Alto","4/21/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Validação Detetor","4224000000696","(09/09/2024) O prazo de implementação desta medida é de 18 months after the date of notification of this Decision. Este prazo é provisório até recebermos confirmation letter.

596,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","SME Retail","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","6","Weaknesses in the calculation of realised LGD
There is a misalignment between the LGD estimates under assessment and the current CCF estimates used in the
Supervised Entity, in what concerns the reflection of additional drawings after default in the EAD, which is considered for
the LGD but not for the CCF and causes a lowering effect in the final LGD estimates not compensated by the CCF
estimates applied.
Regarding the recovery cash-flows stemming from repossessed and sold collaterals the following issues were identified:
- the Supervised Entity is excluding possible increases in collateral valuation between repossession date and
the sales date from the considered sale cash-flow, which constitute an unfounded change to the observed
sale value.

- the recovery cash-flows values are discounted in three different ways: (i) from the intra-month date to the endof-month date, (ii) then all values from the sales date to the repossession date and (iii) from the repossession
date to the default date, using distinct discount rates for each of them.
The Supervised Entity estimates a fixed monthly indirect cost amount per facility based on recovery processes of all
portfolios within the Supervised Entity and applied it only to the monthly positions when the facilities are in a specific
recovery stage, leading to a significant underestimation of the indirect costs applied.
The following shortcomings were identified in the haircut estimation process:
- all repossessed and sold collaterals data were considered, despite pertaining to facilities from portfolios other
than the SME retail portfolio, without ensuring representativeness. Moreover, no comparison was made
between estimated haircuts and observations on repossessions and sales for similar types of collateral;
- the haircut applied assumes a Time to Sell (TTS) for the unsold collaterals equal to that of the sold collaterals
which is not conservative considering that the average TTS for sold collaterals is less than 36 months and the
average time on books of unsold collaterals is greater than 72 months;
- collaterals that were subject to two partial repossessions are contributing twice to the estimation of the
haircuts;
- no sensitivity analyses were performed considering the application of a haircut of 100% to cases where
collateral has been repossessed but not yet sold.
The calculation of the realised LGD presents several shortcomings, that were evidenced by the selected cases analysed,
namely:
- wrongly identified cures due to (i) “lost cases”, and (ii) buyback of sold credit obligations;
- insufficiencies in the heuristic methodology used to identify restructured cases, in particular:
(i) the incorrect identification of a broader scope of involved facilities in specific restructuring events than
the set of facilities actually involved,
(ii) the misidentification of facilities involved in restructuring events, whose original facilities are in other
portfolios, being unduly considered under the SME Retail portfolio. This heuristic methodology failed to
identify these cases because the default date of the restructuring contract is after the restructuring
date;
- duplication of capital amounts: these duplications occur due to internal procedures of the SE where a
“transition account” is temporarily created in the operation system with the same exposure, being regularised
after a short period of time, typically one or two months, leading to wrongly identified increases in the EAD,
followed by a recovery cash-flow in the same amount, which in some cases has a lowering effect on the
realised LGD;
- foreclosure event followed by an unduly calculated artificial cash-flow, due to the fact that the foreclosure
event occurs in the same monthly position as the date of return to non-default status, leading to a duplication
effect where both the foreclosure recovery amount and the calculation of the artificial cash-flow are being
considered;
- sale of credit obligations leading to inflated recovery cash flows, due to the liquidation of due amounts in
operational systems following of the closing process of the contract sold within the credit sale portfolio;
- duplication of direct costs for cases when there are multiple default events for the same facility, Thus, the
institution is considering more direct costs than what was effectively observed which has a conservative effect
in the estimation;
Incorrect recovery cash-flows considered for the calculation of the LGD for the exposure not covered by the
SGM.","O4","The Supervised Entity shall ensure consistency in the EAD definition, particularly considering additional
drawings after default, between LGD and CCF model estimation.

offered rate applicable at the moment of default increased by an add-on of 5%-points. Moreover,

be properly addressed in the LGD realised calculation. In particular, foreclosure events occurring in the
same monthly position as the date of return to non-default status shall not lead to a duplication effect

costs ascertained in the estimation process is reflected in the final RDS.
The Supervised Entity shall enhance the haircut estimation process ensuring the correction of the
issues listed in Finding 6.
The Supervised Entity shall accurately identify each default closing scenario.
The Supervised Entity shall ensure the traceability between restructured and restructuring facilities, at
least enhancing the approach followed to historically identify restructuring events, in order to avoid

597,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","SME Retail","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","7","The LGD model presents deficiencies in the risk differentiation capacity between riskier and less risky defaults.
The Supervised Entity’s methodology for the identification and selection of relevant risk drivers presented several
insufficiencies, namely:
- the list of potential risk drivers does not include institution-related or external factors;
- the set of potential risk drivers was solely considered at the moment of default, as the institution did not
consider relevant to analyse the risk drivers within a year before the default;
- the assessment of risk drivers considered the floored realised LGD which may hinder a correct risk
differentiation analysis;
- it was not properly documented in order to a knowledgeable third party to be able to fully replicate it;
- for the in-default segments, no additional in-default risk drivers were analysed, except the risk drivers already
considered for non-default segments and the number of months after the date of default.
Moreover, the assessment of robustness, stability, concentration, homogeneity, and heterogeneity across the LGD
segments was only performed for the non-default segments and presents the following deficiencies:
- one of the defined segments, namely SGM Non-guaranteed Exposure was not assessed in the testing phase,
as the institution only analysed the estimates of the SGM Total Exposure;
- the robustness assessment is inconclusive, since in the comparison between observed LGD and estimated
LGDs, the observed LGD considers only the closed cases, which by definition is always lower than the final
estimated LGDs that also include open cases;
- high concentration levels, especially in Unsecured without credit line ≤ EUR 500, and Unsecured with credit
line > EUR 500 segments, are verified through the entire RDS and application portfolio. In particular, the three
mentioned segments represent 99.9% of the EAD in the application portfolio, while the five remaining
segments represent in total less than 0.1%. Even in terms of facilities, the four less populated segments all
have less than 0.5% of the total facilities of the application portfolio and all combined account to only 0.75% of
the facilities;
- heterogeneity is not observed across all pairs of segments, in particular the pairs of EAD >EUR 500 and ≤
EUR 500 reveal lack of heterogeneity for segments Secured SGM, Secured Real and Unsecured with credit
line and almost all pools of EAD ≤ EUR 500 revealed heterogeneity issues amongst them;
the assessment performed by the institution was poorly documented and contained several calculation errors
that were only identified during the investigation phase by the AT (even though with no impact on the main

conclusions).",,,"8","1","5","4",," The Supervised Entity is reminded of its duty to ensure compliance with the legal requirements referred to in the respective finding in Annex II and to act accordingly ",,"Risco Médio","10/21/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Suspensa",,"(19/06/2024) The institution’s methodology for the identification and selection of relevant risk drivers presented several insufficiencies, namely: - the list of potential risk drivers does not include institution-related or external factors; - the set of potential risk drivers was solely considered at the moment of default, as the institution did not consider relevant to analyse the risk drivers within a year before the default; - the assessment of risk drivers considered the floored realised LGD which may hinder a correct risk differentiation analysis; - it was not properly documented in order to a knowledgeable third party to be able to fully replicate it; - for the in-default segments, no additional in-default risk drivers were analysed, except the risk drivers already considered for non-default segments and the number of months after the date of default. Moreover, the assessment of robustness, stability, concentration, homogeneity, and heterogeneity across the LGD segments was only performed for the non-default segments and presents the following deficiencies:

- one of the defined segments, namely SGM Non-guaranteed Exposure was not assessed in the testing phase, as the institution only analysed the estimates of the SGM Total Exposure; - the robustness assessment is inconclusive, since in the comparison between observed LGD and estimated LGDs, the observed LGD considers only the closed cases, which by definition is always lower than the final estimated LGDs that also include open cases; - high concentration levels, especially in Unsecured without credit line ≤ EUR 500, and Unsecured with credit line > EUR 500 segments, are verified through the entire RDS and application portfolio. In particular, the three mentioned segments represent 99.9% of the EAD in the application portfolio, while the five remaining segments represent in total less than 0.1%. Even in terms of facilities, the four less populated segments all have less than 0.5% of the total facilities of the application portfolio and all combined account to only 0.75% of the facilities;

heterogeneity is not observed across all pairs of segments, in particular the pairs of EAD >EUR 500 and ≤ EUR 500 reveal lack of heterogeneity for segments Secured SGM, Secured Real and Unsecured with credit line and almost all pools of EAD ≤ EUR 500 revealed heterogeneity issues amongst them; - the assessment performed by the institution was poorly documented and contained several calculation errors that were only identified during the investigation phase by the AT (even though with no impact on the main conclusions).

598,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Gestão e Planeamento de Qualidade do Ativo",,"IRB","LGD","SME Retail","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","8","Deficiencies in the treatment of flows from protection providers and capital requirements calculation
Pursuant to Article 164(2) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “An institution shall not assign guaranteed exposures an
adjusted PD or LGD such that the adjusted risk weight would be lower than that of a comparable, direct exposure to the
guarantor.”
Pursuant to Article 174(c) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “the data used to build the model shall be representative of the
population of the institution's actual obligors or exposures”.
The Supervised Entity is considering cash-flows from protection providers to estimate LGDs to be applied to part of the
exposure that is unsecured, both in the performing and non-performing portfolios.
In the estimation of the LGD for segment “SGM Total exposure”, the Supervised Entity is using facilities whose capital
requirements are calculated under the F-IRB or SA approach (when the substitution approach is applied).
For capital requirements calculation, the Supervised Entity applies a methodology that does not ensure that the adjusted
LGD assigned to guaranteed exposures would not result in the adjusted risk weight being lower than that of a comparable,
direct exposure to the guarantor.
In addition, the Supervised Entity uses two of the methods described in paragraph 31 of EBA/GL/2020/05 for the same
type of UFCP in the same rating system leading to an arbitrage of RWA estimates.
In light of the above, the ECB concludes that the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out for this
finding because it uses cash flows from protection providers to estimate LGDs for unsecured exposures in both performing
and non-performing portfolios. For the ""SGM Total exposure"" segment, the Supervised Entity uses facilities with capital
requirements calculated under the F-IRB or SA approach. The methodology applied does not ensure that the adjusted
LGD for guaranteed exposures results in a risk weight comparable to direct exposure to the guarantor. Additionally, the
entity uses two methods from EBA/GL/2020/05 for the same type of UFCP within the same rating system, leading to an
arbitrage of RWA estimates","O5","The Supervised Entity shall not consider cash-flows from protection providers to estimate LGDs to be
applied to part of the exposure that is unsecured.
The Supervised Entity shall ensure consistency between the LGD estimation and its application,
ensuring that facilities guaranteed by protection providers that, for capital requirements calculation
purposes, are being treated under the substitution of risk parameters approach or the substitution of risk
weight approach, are excluded from the LGD estimation.
For capital requirements calculation, the Supervised Entity shall not assign guaranteed exposures an
adjusted LGD such that the adjusted risk weight would be lower than that of a comparable, direct
exposure to the guarantor.
Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall have clear and consistent policies for assessing the effects of
unfunded credit protection on risk parameters, including in these policies a clear specification of which of
the specific methods described in paragraph 31 of EBA/GL/2020/05 is used for each rating system, and

apply these policies consistently over time. ","4","1","3","4",,,"Limitation 2: The Supervised Entity shall apply a multiplication factor of 1.15 (add-on) to its estimates for the LGD for non-defaulted exposures, LGD for
defaulted exposures and ELBE of the SME Retail portfolio under the scope of this Decision.
The add-on shall be applied for the purpose of calculating RWA and expected loss.

This limitation shall apply until the ECB has confirmed in writing that Obligations 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 have been fulfilled by the Supervised Entity.","Risco Alto","10/21/2026 11:00 PM","Final",,"Em Curso","4224000000698","(09/09/2024) - O prazo de implementação desta medida é de 18 months after the date of notification of this Decision. 599,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","SME Retail","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","9","Insufficiencies in the calculation of long-run average LGD. The Supervised Entity does not take into account the different recovery profiles depending on the type of credit

The treatment of incomplete recovery processes presents the following insufficiencies:
- In the calculation of recovery rates profile per end-state, full write-offs and debt liquidation are both considered

- The estimated cash-flows are being discounted to the default date twice due to an operational error.

Moreover, there is an error in the calculation of the average realised LGD for obligors with bank guarantees and other

600,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","SME Retail","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","10","Weaknesses in the downturn LGD quantification
Pursuant to Article 181(1)(b) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “institutions shall use LGD estimates that are appropriate

for an economic downturn if those are more conservative than the long-run average. To the extent a rating system is expected to deliver realised LGDs at a constant level by grade or pool over time, institutions shall make adjustments to
their estimates of risk parameters by grade or pool to limit the capital impact of an economic downturn”.
With regards to the estimation of an LGD appropriate for an economic downturn:
- The Supervised Entity did not properly take into account potential lags between the downturn period and the
time when its potential impact is observed on the relevant loss data.
- The Supervised Entity did not analyse the appropriateness of introducing calibration segments that cover
material shares of exposure in different industry sectors or different product types.
- The Supervised Entity did not properly justify the material difference between the final downturn LGD and the
reference value.
Moreover, the calculation of the reference value presents the following insufficiencies:
- Instead of using the simple average of the average realised LGDs from the two individual years with the highest
observed economic losses, the average of the average realised LGDs weighted by the number of defaults in
each year was used.
- The open facilities that have reached the maximum time-to-workout until the cut-off date were excluded from
the calculation.
The calibration of downturn LGD for segments with EAD≤EUR 500 is not adequate. The Supervised Entity used a
calibration based on the type 3 approach of EBA/GL/2019/03 but loss data to assess the impact of the downturn LGD is
available.
In light of the above, the ECB concludes that the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out for this
finding because it did not properly consider potential lags between the economic downturn and its impact on relevant loss
data. The Supervised Entity did not analyse the need for calibration segments covering different industry sectors or product
types and did not justify the significant difference between the final downturn LGD and the reference value. The reference
value calculation was flawed as it used weighted averages instead of simple averages of the highest loss years and
excluded open facilities that reached the maximum time-to-workout. Additionally, the calibration of downturn LGD for
segments with EAD≤EUR 500 was not adequate, using a type 3 approach despite having loss data available to assess
the impact.
,O6","For the purpose of quantifying downturn LGD, the Supervised Entity shall:
- at least consider the appropriateness of introducing calibration segments that cover material
shares of exposure in different geographical areas, in different industry sectors and of different
product types;
- properly take into account potential lags between the downturn period and the time when its
potential impact is observed on the relevant loss data.
The Supervised Entity shall properly justify and document any material difference between the DT LGD
estimates and the reference value. Moreover, the Supervised Entity shall calculate the reference value
according to paragraph 37 of EBA/GL/2019/03, in particular using all available loss data and
considering the simple average of the average realised LGDs from the two individual years with the
highest observed economic losses.
Additionally, considering the Supervised Entity has sufficient and relevant loss data related to the SME

Retail portfolio to conduct the impact analysis set out in paragraph 27 of EBA/GL/2019/03, the downturn LGD for the considered downturn period shall be calibrated in accordance with Section 5 of the referred
guidelines.","3","1",,"3",,,"Limitation 2: The Supervised Entity shall apply a multiplication factor of 1.15 (add-on) to its estimates for the LGD for non-defaulted exposures, LGD for
defaulted exposures and ELBE of the SME Retail portfolio under the scope of this Decision.
The add-on shall be applied for the purpose of calculating RWA and expected loss.

This limitation shall apply until the ECB has confirmed in writing that Obligations 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 have been fulfilled by the Supervised Entity","Risco Alto","10/21/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","4224000000699","(09/09/2024) - O prazo de implementação desta medida é de18 months after the

601,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","SME Retail","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","11","Shortcomings in the LGD MoC quantification
Pursuant to Article 179(1)(f) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “institutions shall add to its estimates a margin of
conservatism that is related to the expected range of estimation errors. Where methods and data are considered to be less
satisfactory, the expected range of errors is larger, the margin of conservatism shall be larger.”
Pursuant to Article 47 of the Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 439/2022, “competent authorities shall assess
whether an appropriate margin of conservatism is included in the values of risk parameters used in the calculation of capital
requirements as referred to in point (f) of Article 179(1) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, in the following situations: (a) the
methods and data do not provide sufficient certainty of the risk parameter estimates, including where there are high
estimation errors; (b) relevant deficiencies in the methods, information and data have been identified by the credit risk
control unit, validation function or internal audit function or any other function of the institution; (c) relevant changes to the
standards of underwriting or recovery policies or changes in the institution’s risk appetite.”
The Supervised Entity did not identify all data and methodology deficiencies related to the estimation of LGD estimates
that should have been assessed under a MoC of category A. At least the following sources of uncertainty were not
considered:
- methodology for obtained cashflows as the difference between the exposure amounts.
- assumptions considered in the “lost cases”.
- algorithm for identification of restructuring situations.
Moreover, the following insufficiencies were identified in the MoC A quantification:
- the Supervised Entity uses a methodology to calculate the appropriate adjustment due to the insufficiency of
default historical information related to Triggers T04 and T06B that is not adequate and there is no certainty that it would
reflect a better estimate of the LGDs.
- the Supervised Entity did not adequately document nor justify the methodology and underlying assumptions for
the appropriate adjustment related with the insufficiency of indirect costs. The Supervised Entity is applying an adjustment
to the LGD estimates directly as calculated by the validation function. The development team demonstrated no knowledge
about the assumptions underlying this adjustment.
Furthermore, the Supervised Entity did not consider any MoC B (neither in LGD performing nor in LGD in-default

estimates), despite the structural changes occurred in the recovery processes over the years observed in the RDS. The analysis performed are insufficient and the conclusions are inconsistent with the ones obtained from the downturn period
impact analysis.
Finally, the MoC C was calculated using the LRA LGD and not considering the downturn period.
In light of the above, the ECB concludes that the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out for this
finding because it failed to identify all data and methodology deficiencies related to LGD estimates that should have been
assessed under MoC category A. Specifically, it did not consider uncertainties related to the methodology for obtaining
cash flows, assumptions in “lost cases,” and the algorithm for identifying restructuring situations. Additionally, the
methodology for adjusting LGD estimates due to insufficient historical default information was inadequate, and the
adjustments related to indirect costs were not properly documented or justified. The Supervised Entity also did not consider
any MoC B adjustments, despite structural changes in recovery processes observed over the years. Finally, the MoC C
calculation used the LRA LGD without considering the downturn period.
,O7","The Supervised Entity shall review its process of identifying the sources of uncertainty during the
estimation process of risk parameters to ensure that all required and appropriate Margin of
Conservatism adjustments are identified, assessed and quantified in order to obtain the most accurate
estimates possible. At least, the following additional sources of uncertainty shall be assessed: i)
methodology for obtained cashflows as the difference between the exposure amounts; ii) assumptions
considered in the “lost cases”; iii) algorithm for identification of restructuring situations.
Regarding the quantification of identified sources of uncertainty, the Supervised Entity shall:
- review the methodology to calculate the appropriate adjustment due to the insufficiency of
default historical information related to Triggers T04 and T06B, ensuring that the adjusted LGD
would reflect a better estimate of the LGDs and providing clear evidence supporting that the
defaults not included in the RDS would have lower realised LGDs. Moreover, the adjustment
and respective MoC A shall be calculated considering the same assumptions.
- adequately document and justify the methodology and underlying assumptions for the
appropriate adjustment related with the insufficiency of indirect costs, ensuring that the
development team has detailed knowledge of the assumptions underlying this adjustment.
The structural changes occurred in the recovery processes over the years observed in the RDS shall be
properly analysed and taken into account in a MoC B.

Regarding the MoC C, the Supervised Entity shall calculate it considering the downturn period.","5","3",,"5",,,"Limitation 2: The Supervised Entity shall apply a multiplication factor of 1.15 (add-on) to its estimates for the LGD for non-defaulted exposures, LGD for
defaulted exposures and ELBE of the SME Retail portfolio under the scope of this Decision.
The add-on shall be applied for the purpose of calculating RWA and expected loss.

This limitation shall apply until the ECB has confirmed in writing that Obligations 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 have been fulfilled by the Supervised Entity.","Risco Alto","10/21/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","4224000000700","(09/09/2024) - O prazo de implementação desta medida é 18 months after the

602,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GDM",,,"IRB","LGD","SME Retail","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","12","Deficiencies in the estimation of ELBE and LGD in-default
Pursuant to Article 179(1)(f) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “institutions shall add to its estimates a margin of
conservatism that is related to the expected range of estimation errors. Where methods and data are considered to be
less satisfactory, the expected range of errors is larger, the margin of conservatism shall be larger.”
Pursuant to Article 181(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “institutions shall estimate LGDs by facility grade or pool
on the basis of the average realised LGDs by facility grade or pool using all observed defaults within the data sources
(default weighted average);
Pursuant to Article 181(1)(h) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013, “for the specific case of exposures already in default, the
institution shall use the sum of its best estimate of expected loss for each exposure given current economic
circumstances and exposure status and its estimate of the increase of loss rate caused by possible additional
unexpected losses during the recovery period, i.e. between date of default and final liquidation of the exposure.”
Despite having monthly reference dates data available, the Supervised Entity decided to set reference dates that would
result in only four pools for each segment, resulting in non-homogeneous pools that do not appropriately consider the
recovery patterns observed. For instance, for segment “Secured with SGM with EAD>EUR 500”, in pool 6<TiD≤18, with
an ELBE of 43.6%, the ELBE for the lower limit of the monthly reference date (Time in Default (TiD)=7) is 33.5% while
for the upper limit (TiD=18) is 56%.
The Supervised Entity estimated the ELBE as the long-run average LGD for defaulted exposures without assessing if it
reflects current economic conditions. Moreover, the Supervised Entity is applying an ELBE less than 100% after the

maximum time-to-workout, namely in segments “SGM Total exposure”, “Secured with collateral” and “Unsecured Credit”. Additionally, the estimation of the ELBE is incorrect due to an algorithmic error that occurs when a pool has facilities that
start after the date of default.
The Supervised Entity did not perform an impact analysis of the downturn period in the in-default LGD.
The Supervised Entity is not including the general estimation error (MoC C) in the final LGD in-default estimates.
Furthermore, the Supervised Entity has estimated the ELBE and LGD in-default considering a cap of 100% and 105%,
respectively, and did not perform back-testing nor benchmarking in the ELBE and LGD in-default estimates.
In light of the above, the ECB concludes that the Supervised Entity does not fulfil the legal requirements set out for this
finding because it set reference dates resulting in only four pools per segment, leading to non-homogeneous pools that do
not appropriately consider recovery patterns. For example, in the segment “Secured with SGM with EAD>EUR 500”,
significant discrepancies were observed within the same pool. The Supervised Entity estimated the ELBE as the long-run
average LGD for defaulted exposures without assessing if it reflects current economic conditions and applied an ELBE
less than 100% after the maximum time-to-workout in several segments. Additionally, an algorithmic error in the ELBE
estimation occurred when a pool had facilities that started after the date of default. The Supervised Entity did not analyse
the impact of the downturn period on LGD in-default, nor did it include the general estimation error (MoC C) in the final
LGD in-default estimates. Furthermore, it applied caps of 100% and 105% to the ELBE and LGD in-default estimates,
respectively, without performing back-testing or benchmarking.","O8","The Supervised Entity shall select the reference dates for the calculation of the realised LGD for ELBE
and LGD DA, based on groups which are aligned with the recovery patterns observed, ensuring their
homogeneity.
The Supervised Entity shall ensure that the ELBE estimates reflect current economic conditions. The

ELBE shall be sustained by empirical evidence obtained from historical information, so that the final value is justified by itself and is comparable with the LRA LGD and defined maximum time-to-workout, in
order to evaluate the consistency of the model and consider this result for adapting the model.
The Supervised Entity shall perform an impact analysis of the downturn period in the LGD in-default and
shall include the general estimation error (MoC C) in the final LGD in-default estimates.

The Supervised Entity shall not apply any cap to the ELBE and LGD in-default and shall perform backtesting and benchmarking in the ELBE and LGD in-default estimates","5",,,"5",,,,"Risco Alto","10/21/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","4224000000701","(09/09/2024) O prazo de implementação desta medida é de 18 months after the
date of notification
of this Decision. Este prazo é provisório até recebermos confirmation letter.",,,"6/19/2024 08:41 AM","3/18/2025 04:22 AM"

603,"IMI-2023-PTNOB-0220651.pdf","10/21/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","GVM",,,"IRB","PD e LGD","Pequenas e Médias Empresas","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","13","Insufficiencies in the validation exercise
The validation exercises performed to the development of the new PD calibrations and new LGD model are incomplete
and, in some cases, inadequate, since not all key aspects of the material changes proposed were fully and critically
assessed.
Concerning the PD validation exercise:
- The validation report on the PD calibration of small enterprises is unclear regarding the tests performed on the
final bucketing proposed. Moreover, some tests were not performed in the final grades proposed, such as
homogeneity and granularity.
- The validation exercise performed on the PD calibration of medium enterprises was not complete, as the
calibration exercise itself was not complete. Furthermore, the validation team did not guarantee that the
calibration exercise addressed the obligations issued in ECB/SSM/2022 (PTNOB-10), especially in what

concerns the documentation of choice of risk drivers and bucketing. Moreover, the validation function raises a finding based purely on the high impact of the MoC C without any methodological challenge or quantitative
analyses supporting it.
Regarding the LGD validation exercise:
- GVM approved the final LGD estimates without analysing neither the final report of the development team, nor
the support information to the LGD estimates, compromising the challenge performed by the validation team,
which is evidenced by the misidentification of some issues raised by the AT concerning several aspects of the
LGD estimation process that are not compliant with the regulation. A particular example of that is the lack of
assessment of GVM of the LGD in-default model.
- Besides a high severity finding on documentation, no other finding was issued by GVM, concerning the key
aspects of the LGD estimation process that were not assessed due to lack of information and, on the contrary,
the overall assessment of GVM of the main aspects of the LGD estimation identified all those topics with a
green status.
,O9","The Validation function of the Supervised Entity shall:
- ensure that all the procedures or guidelines set in the validation framework are
comprehensively and consistently executed;
- critically and independently review and challenge all the aspects of the specification of the
internal ratings and risk parameters, including the procedures for data collection and data
cleansing, the underlying assumptions, the choices of the methodology and model
structure/components, as well as the respective compliance with the applicable regulation
and obligations of previous supervisory decisions;
- enhance its reporting documentation in order to be comprehensively understandable by a
third party the work performed by the internal validation regarding each rating system,

including which key aspects were not possible to assess due to lack of information.","3",,,"3","GVM will comply with regulatory requirements and enhance its validation framework in a new version (21) by 31.12.2025, allowing sufficient time for the audit function to complete its review within the regulatory deadline. For the initial validations scheduled over the next 18 months, efforts will also be made to ensure that the final validation report meets regulatory expectations in terms of completeness and detail, thus facilitating third-party understanding of the work performed, judgments made, and conclusions reached by GVM in fulfilling its validation responsibilities.",,,"Risco Alto","4/21/2026 12:00 AM","Final",,"Em Curso","4224000000702","(09/09/2024) O prazo de implementação desta medida é de 18 months after the
date of notification
of this Decision. Este prazo é provisório até recebermos confirmation letter.

615,"PTNOB_2023_ILAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ILAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Modelo","4","Novo Banco should provide additional details on the stress scenario risk drivers","4","Novo Banco should provide additional details on the stress scenario risk drivers (including for the ones considered immaterial), comprehensive quantification of the material risk drivers, quantitative impact of risk drivers considered immaterial (for drivers where such was not provided) and justification / rationale for using a specific type of stress (e.g. based on historical data vs. market / industry data).","1",,,"1",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(21/06/2024) Although more detail on the risk identification and quantification assumptions for the stress tests was provided, there are still shortcomings. An assessment of individual risk drivers is provided in Annex 2 to better illustrate our concerns.

For some of the immaterial risk drivers, the explanations provided are enough for one to understand the materiality assessment. For others though, it’s unclear how the quantification was made (e.g. shadow banking risk, foreign exchange convertibility). There are also some concerns regarding the conservativism of the assumptions in the non-material risks and unclear outcomes (e.g. deterioration of the firm’s credit rating, non-marketable assets risk, impact on the firm’s reputation).

For the risk drivers deemed material, there are some cases of well explained rationales and assumptions, yet for others such is not provided. Also, there are doubts regarding the conservativism on the quantification impact of some risk drivers (e.g. for the wholesale secured funding or marketable assets risk (see Annex 2 for details).

The JST acknowledges positive developments, namely on the concentration risk and intraday risk drivers. However, for wholesale secured funding risk and cyber risk, which were specifically highlighted in the previous ILAAP exercise feedback, the issues remain unaddressed: the rational for the impact of EUR 141 million of cyber risk is not sufficiently clear and the impact on the wholesale funding risk is missing. Also, the specific highlighted cases in the previous ILAAP exercise feedback were clearly provided as examples, meaning that the bank should not limit its analysis to these.

618,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","1","Novo Banco should explain and document in more detail and with greater clarity how the Economic Capital surplus feeds into the setting of the risk limits in the RAS","1","Novo Banco should explain and document in more detail and with greater clarity how the Economic Capital surplus feeds into the setting of the risk limits in the RAS. Furthermore, Novo Banco should provide evidence that it monitors the available Economic Capital and its surplus evolution with the right parameters/elements monthly (e.g., by referencing in the ICAAP to the relevant documents which are then submitted in the ICAAP package). In its internal policies it should also document what the monthly and quarterly monitoring consist of.","3",,"1","2",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(25/06/2024) The JST has identified areas where the interplay between ICAAP and RAF lacks clarity. According to the internal documentation the RAS metrics are calibrated based on the Economic Capital (EC) surplus. It is unclear how exactly that calibration takes place. For instance, the “Economic View Capital Surplus” is a Level 1 RAS metric and derived from the ICAAP. From the RAF or any other documentation, it is not shown how this surplus feeds into the setting of the limits. For example, the IRRBB red limit is EUR 450mn compared to the ICAAP economic capital requirement of EUR 283mn (YE2023). It is unclear how the bank calibrated and justified the limit of EUR 450mn and how the level relates to the EC surplus. For example it is not clear if a reduction in the EC surplus would trigger a review and potential reduction of the IRRBB limit. , In this context we would like to stress that the risk appetite should be the main component to set limits.

Apart from the IRRBB limit the link between the EC requirements from the ICAAP and the RAS limits for the different risks are not clear as in the RAS i) shorter time horizons are used2; ii) different risk parameters or methodologies are used3; and/or iii) relevant EC contributors are not listed in the RAS4. Except for the overall economic capital number in the risk dashboard the JST has no evidence that DRG monitors the economic available capital and its surplus evolution with the right parameters/elements monthly.

The RAS on a standalone basis cannot provide a complete and overall understanding of how various types of risks (such as market, credit, and pension fund risks) affect the economic capital surplus. The monitoring of EC is particularly crucial as it is a critical input when considering and setting the investment portfolio’s RAS limit. One can argue that for the addressee of the RAS (Management Board) the overview of the EC surplus alone is sufficient to get an understanding of the risk evolution. But even assuming DRG has all this information monthly – for which the JST has no evidence – it should be clearer spelled out in the RAF/ICAAP and maybe even included in the Level 2 RAS.

622,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Documentos","2.2","Novo Banco is recommended to ensure that it progresses on the implementation of a comprehensive and more granular capital allocation framework, in order to adequately use it for business steering and decision-making purposes.","2.2","Novo Banco is recommended to ensure that it progresses on the implementation of a comprehensive and more granular capital allocation framework, in order to adequately use it for business steering and decision-making purposes. For that it is asked to present a plan by the 30 September 2024 how to enhance and operationalise its capital allocation methodology to enable the quantification of risk-adjusted profitability of the various segments and develop a granular view of the credit stock portfolio. Once finalised, the framework should be documented as part of the ICAAP.","3",,"1","2",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(25/06/2024) The capital allocation in chapter 11 is only shown for the economic but not the normative view. Furthermore, the capital allocation is an ex post top-down approach with low granularity and hence no real steering capability (beyond the monitoring of the “default risk capital” metrics clearly included in the RAF). Novo Banco states that further work will be required to operationalise its capital allocation methodology to enable the quantification of risk-adjusted profitability of the various segments and therefore support its strategic planning process, i.e. applying a more bottom up allocation approach. In addition, please explain in the ICAAP, like in the recovery plan, why the management buffer size of 100bps is considered adequate.","2.3.1","It should be ensured that the RAF/RAS limits and the internal CET1 targets are consistently calibrated and reported within the different exercises (ICAAP, RAF, Recovery Plan). In case mismatches stem from time lags between the finalisation of different exercises, this should be made explicit, to avoid any risk of confusion. In addition, please explain in the ICAAP, like in the recovery plan, why the management buffer size of 100bps is considered adequate.","2",,"1","1",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 11:00 PM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(25/06/2024) There is a discrepancy between the RAF/RAS and the CET1 target which includes the management buffer. According to the ICAAP, the risk appetite framework for the CET1 ratio is calibrated so that the green zone is achieved when the Bank is above the CET1 target (13.56%, i.e. including the management buffer)6. In the RAS the green zone is defined at 13.31%.7 In the Recovery Plan (submitted Dec-23) the bank’s RAS includes the 13.56% with a footnote that the limit changes to 13.31% in 2024 without providing any reasoning. In the ICAAP (submitted Mar-24) there is no explanation at all. That means, essentially, that the ICAAP’s RAF is inconsistent with the setting of the internal capital target and currently the management buffer as defined in the ICAAP is not reflected in the RAS and hence not monitored. In addition, Novo Banco did not elaborate in the ICAAP documentation the reasoning for why the management buffer size of exactly 100bps is adequate.

626,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","3.1","When designing its stress tests, Novo Banco should consider different scenarios with a focus on key vulnerabilities which are expected to result in a material impact on the institution’s internal and regulatory capital.","3.1","When designing its stress tests, Novo Banco should consider different scenarios with a focus on key vulnerabilities which are expected to result in a material impact on the institution’s internal and regulatory capital. Novo Banco should thus follow paragraph 92 of the ECB ICAAP Guide, i.e. “when defining stress-testing scenarios, e.g. for the projections under the normative perspective, institutions are expected to capture their material vulnerabilities, given their individual business model, risk profile and the external conditions they face. Other stress tests conducted, e.g. sensitivity analysis, are expected to inform the scenarios used by revealing the material vulnerabilities of the institution.” In addition, the bank should better justify the key financial implications of their stress scenario, e.g. why the bond yields are decreasing in a rising interest rate environment under stress.","3",,"2","1",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(26/06/2024) The adverse scenario includes a stress on equity prices and overall addresses all material pain points of the bank, which constitutes an improvement compared to last year. Nevertheless, its level of severity still raises questions since it assumes an increase of interest rates in 2024, which benefits the bank in terms of NII both in 2024 and 2025. The JST acknowledges the relevance of such scenario from a macroeconomic point of view and for the purpose of aligning the adverse scenario between the MTP and the ICAAP. However, given the fact that the bank is currently negatively exposed to a decrease of interest rates, the bank could have considered an alternative adverse scenario based on the assumption of a sharper recession already from the beginning of 2024, leading to cuts in interest rates (and hence lower NII). In that regard, the JST highlights that the ECB ICAAP Guide considers the possibility of including multiple adverse scenarios in the ICAAP. Furthermore, the decrease of bonds’ yields benefits the bank in terms of OCI impact, but the bank doesn’t adequately justify why the bond yields are decreasing in a rising interest rate environment under stress in the year 2024.

630,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","5.1.1","The bank should refrain from using corporate customers deposits to reduce RWA of certain credit exposures with the form loans under Pillar 2 as currently done","5.1.1","The bank should refrain from using corporate customers deposits to reduce RWA of certain credit exposures with the form loans under Pillar 2 as currently done, irrespective of the outcome of the said OSI in relation to the Pillar 1 treatment.","1",,"1",,,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(26/06/2024) The “RWA accuracy project” introduced the implementation of “on-balance sheet netting” which is also being assessed in an on-site inspection (OSI) starting in the first quarter 2024. This initiative aims to use corporate customers deposits (liabilities) to reduce RWA of certain (on-balance) sheet credit exposures with the form loans by using those deposits as credit risk mitigation after considering certain eligibility condition and – according to the bank – in accordance with CRR rules. The bulk of the EAD stems from MLT credit to corporates and the deposits are mainly demand/operational deposits.10 Regardless of whether this mitigating technique were to be compatible with Pillar 1 it is doubtful that it is adequate from an economic value consideration. The deposits cannot provide any stability in terms of risk mitigation from an economic perspective and considering them as netting factor contradicts the expectation of the risk quantification methodologies and assumptions used under the economic perspective, namely that they are expected to be robust, sufficiently stable, risk sensitive, and conservative enough to quantify losses that occur rarely.

631,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","5.1.2","First, to be very consistent in its argumentation the bank should also check the credit and balance sheet growth of the first two months of the current year and increase capital requirements in case of growth beyond the YE2023","5.1.2","First, to be very consistent in its argumentation the bank should also check the credit and balance sheet growth of the first two months of the current year and increase capital requirements in case of growth beyond the YE2023, just as the actual profits of the first two months are included in internal capital. Second, the bank should enhance its RWA evolution in the ICAAP’s adverse scenario to ensure a clear differentiation can be made between the effects from an economic deterioration, namely a risk parameter (RWA) increase on the one hand and lower RWA through lower volumes on the other hand.","2",,"2",,,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(26/06/2024) The bank incorporates the adverse scenario in the economic view by including only the profits from the adverse scenario in the internal capital. According to the bank, under the adverse scenario no RWA/business growth is expected and hence no need to include additional capital requirements to the point-in-time YE2023 status. The bank argues that the projections for the RWAs on the credit risk present a decreasing trend in the adverse scenario. From the ICAAP’s documentation it is unclear whether the credit risk RWAs under the adverse scenario also reflect a deterioration of the credit portfolio (and ensuing higher risk weights) or are only lower due to a slower credit growth between 2024-2026. If only the latter is considered, the proposed approach is inconsistent. On the same token, the JST’s recommendation from last year - in the adverse scenarios there is no detail of the RWA evolution per risk type, which provides limited information and challenging ground on the RWA implications for readers such as the supervisor or senior management – is not remedied (see stress test section). Otherwise, this unclarity would not exist in the ICAAP documentation.

632,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","5.1.3","Novo Banco should provide sufficient justification for deeming certain subcategories as non-material","5.1.3","Novo Banco should provide sufficient justification for deeming certain subcategories as non-material. It should also more clearly set out why certain subcategories of the credit default risk are quantified (even if only in terms of RWA), while others are referred to as being part of the overall credit default risk.","2",,"1","1",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(26/06/2024) For risk identification, despite the recommendations issued in the previous year, the ICAAP report does not sufficiently justify why the 7 subcategories are deemed non-material. Despite the low severity attributed, the assessment of the following risks is not documented: country risk, FX lending risk, settlement and delivery risk, and wrong assessment risk. Migration risk, wrong-way risk and residual risk are briefly explained but no quantification is made (including quantification of exposures or portfolios that could be subject to these risks). Finally, in last year’s ICAAP report certain sub-categories were said to be part of the overall credit default risk and are now detailed in a dedicated sub-section. While this is deemed positive, it is not possible to understand why certain subcategories in this sub-section are quantified (even if only in terms of RWA) and others are once again referred to as being part of the overall credit default risk. With this in mind, it is not possible to consider that recommendation 3.1.1 from last year’s ICAAP letter12 has been fully implemented.

636,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","5.2.1","NB is recommend to hold capital to cover for potential losses arising from such reputational risks","5.2.1","NB is recommended to document in the ICAAP i) the methodology how it quantifies the severity and likelihood of reputational risk in the risk materiality assessment with a view to calculating the capital requirements (i.e. not considering the effects from the adverse scenario impacting the internal capital) and ii) if it is above the absolute threshold (which seems to be the case in the ICAAP 2023 even though it is not fully clear)17 to hold capital to cover for potential losses arising from such reputational risks.","2",,,"2",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(26/06/2024) Reputational risk: The bank does not consider any additional requirements under Pillar 2 for reputational risk even though it identified it as medium likelihood/severity which according to the internal methodology is material if above the absolute threshold of EUR 25mn. However, it is not clear how much the impact is from reputational risk and thus why it is below the EUR 25mn threshold. The reason for not quantifying reputational risk as described in that chapter is that the bank argues that it considers a cyber-attack in the adverse scenario which feeds into the economic view through the projected profits for the next 12 months. Furthermore, the bank argues that the bank’s standing and perception has improved in the last years and is now in line with its peers.

The JST is of the view that the above arguments for abstaining from capitalising for reputational risk are not convincing. First, the fact that the bank’s reputation has seemingly improved, even when in line with peers, does not exclude per se the risk of a future event which causes a negative perception of the institution’s public image. Second, the benchmarking exercise concluded that the majority of the banks quantify this risk15 and that Novo Banco is not aligned with its peers with respect to reputational risk.16 Novo Banco claims that it includes reputational risk as part of its operational risk but according to the internal documentation this is not the case on the capital requirement side. Third, the cyber-attack from the adverse scenario cannot solely cover for potential unexpected losses arising from damages in Novo Banco’s image, just like capital requirements on operational risks (or e.g. credit risk) cannot be reduced simply because this risk is also considered in the adverse scenario which feeds into internal capital through the adjusted projected profits.

637,"ECB_DGUDI 2024 0402_PTNOB_2023_ICAAP_Feedback_letter.docx","6/14/2024 12:00 AM","Supervisor","DRG","DRG Riscos de Mercados",,"ICAAP","N/A","N/A","Em Produção","Deficiência de Processo","5.2.2.","The ECB C&E Guide recommends in expectation 7.6 and 7.7 that institutions are expected to assess the impact of climate-related and environmental risks on their capital adequacy from an economic and a normative perspective and to evaluate the appropriateness of their identification","5.2.2","The ECB C&E Guide recommends in expectation 7.6 and 7.7 that institutions are expected to assess the impact of climate-related and environmental risks on their capital adequacy from an economic and a normative perspective and to evaluate the appropriateness of their identification, measurement and mitigation instruments for climate-related and environmental risks in their periodic reviews. Even though the bank considers C&E risk to materialise only in the mid-to long-term, the normative and economic perspective should mutually inform each other and also potential effects that go beyond the one-year economic perspective should affect the economic value. Novo Banco should thus enhance the quality and elaborateness of the quantification of ESG risk in line with the ECB C&E Guide in its ICAAP.","3",,"2","1",,,,"N/A","3/15/2025 12:00 AM","Final",,"Cancelada",,"(26/06/2024) ESG risk: the bank calculated the P2 capital requirements for physical risk by stressing the LGD resulting from the devaluation of the associated collaterals. For the devaluation of the collateral it takes the development in house prices in 2024 which is taken from the house price variation from the hot house world scenario provided by the Network of Central Banks and Supervisors for Greening the Financial System (NGFS). As in this scenario the house price increase is so sharp (20% in 2024, 45% in 2025) the bank takes a devaluation of 1.2% in 2024 taken from the previous year’s forecast for 2023.18 The logic from the NGFS hot house scenario seems flawed with respect to collateral (and thus LGD) valuation as the house price increases seem to relate to the existing unaffected homes rather than the entire stock, including the affected which are also used as collateral and thus drive the LGD. The approach NB follows is therefore too simplistic. LGDs could also be impacted by transition risk e.g. when EPC certificates become worse (CRE/RRE). For physical risk, notably fire and flood, a differentiation into location by the collateral would make the risk quantification more meaningful. The bank itself has identified that the ESG risk assessment and quantification methodologies need to be improved with a view to determining the qualitative and quantitative impact on credit risk (see Future Plans under the ICAAP chapter 7).
